revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-29 19:20:54.000000000', 'message': "Retry update_user when sqlalchemy raises StaleDataErrors

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication attempts for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data when updating
password expiration for old passwords, which happens when setting a new
password for a user.

This commit attempts to handle that case more gracefully than throwing a
500 by detecting StaleDataErrors from sqlalchemy and retrying.  The
identity sql backend will retry the request for clients that have
stale data change from underneath them.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753
(cherry picked from commit ceae3566e83b26fd6a1679154eae9b0cef29da64)
"}]
commit_message:
Retry update_user when sqlalchemy raises StaleDataErrors

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication attempts for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data when updating
password expiration for old passwords, which happens when setting a new
password for a user.

This commit attempts to handle that case more gracefully than throwing a
500 by detecting StaleDataErrors from sqlalchemy and retrying.  The
identity sql backend will retry the request for clients that have
stale data change from underneath them.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753
(cherry picked from commit ceae3566e83b26fd6a1679154eae9b0cef29da64)

commit_message:
Update naming rule of aspect_id and VDU

The logic for ScalingAspects is updated to remove unnecessary
naming rule that aspect_id and VDU description name should be
the same.

A new naming rule that the VDU description names should be
lowercase to uses them as resource name in Kubernetes, which only
supports lowercase for their resource name.

Change-Id: Ica84b5c97eb84546df669c087ec34027d11efbba

commit_message:
Charm-helpers sync for wallaby bundles

In order to get the ball rolling with keystone, glance needs to
know about wallaby so that it can install in keystone's functional
tests.   This sync just teaches glance about wallaby.

Change-Id: I23f286fd1175c01883a8eb19d3e52c2a30a38dda

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-04 14:27:33.000000000', 'message': 'Always reset CONF when starting the wsgi app

This ensures that options loaded during any prior run of the application
are dropped before being added again during init_application.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1882094

Change-Id: I2bd360dcc6501feea7baf02d4510b282205fc061
'}, {'created': '2020-10-03 02:41:44.000000000', 'message': 'Initialize global data separately and run_once in WSGI app init

We have discovered that if an exception is raised at any point during
the running of the init_application WSGI script in an apache/mod_wsgi
Daemon Mode environment, it will prompt apache/mod_wsgi to re-run the
script without starting a fresh python process. Because we initialize
global data structures during app init, subsequent runs of the script
blow up as some global data do *not* support re-initialization. It is
anyway not safe to assume that init of global data is safe to run
multiple times.

This mod_wsgi behavior appears to be a special situation that does not
behave the same as a normal reload in Daemon Mode as the script file is
being reloaded upon failure instead of the daemon process being
shutdown and restarted as described in the documentation [1].

In order to handle this situation, we can move the initialization of
global data structures to a helper method that is decorated to run only
once per python interpreter instance. This way, we will not attempt to
re-initialize global data that are not safe to init more than once.

TODO: Add test coverage for this

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1882094

[1] https://modwsgi.readthedocs.io/en/develop/user-guides/reloading-source-code.html#reloading-in-daemon-mode

Change-Id: I2bd360dcc6501feea7baf02d4510b282205fc061

the running of the init_application WSGI script in an apache/mod_wsgi
Daemon Mode environment, it will prompt apache/mod_wsgi to re-run the
script without starting a fresh python process. Because we initialize
global data structures during app init, subsequent runs of the script
blow up as some global data do *not* support re-initialization. It is
anyway not safe to assume that init of global data is safe to run
multiple times.

This mod_wsgi behavior appears to be a special situation that does not
behave the same as a normal reload in Daemon Mode as the script file is
being reloaded upon failure instead of the daemon process being
shutdown and restarted as described in the documentation [1].

In order to handle this situation, we can move the initialization of
global data structures to a helper method that is decorated to run only
once per python interpreter instance. This way, we will not attempt to
re-initialize global data that are not safe to init more than once.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1882094

commit_message:
Initialize global data separately and run_once in WSGI app init

We have discovered that if an exception is raised at any point during
the running of the init_application WSGI script in an apache/mod_wsgi
Daemon Mode environment, it will prompt apache/mod_wsgi to re-run the
script without starting a fresh python process. Because we initialize
global data structures during app init, subsequent runs of the script
blow up as some global data do *not* support re-initialization. It is
anyway not safe to assume that init of global data is safe to run
multiple times.

This mod_wsgi behavior appears to be a special situation that does not
behave the same as a normal reload in Daemon Mode as the script file is
being reloaded upon failure instead of the daemon process being
shutdown and restarted as described in the documentation [1].

In order to handle this situation, we can move the initialization of
global data structures to a helper method that is decorated to run only
once per python interpreter instance. This way, we will not attempt to
re-initialize global data that are not safe to init more than once.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1882094

[1] https://modwsgi.readthedocs.io/en/develop/user-guides/reloading-source-code.html#reloading-in-daemon-mode

Change-Id: I2bd360dcc6501feea7baf02d4510b282205fc061

commit_message:
Separate tosca logic from heat infra driver

Tosca code including parser and translator functionalities have
been moved to a separate dir. of their own.

Change-Id: I85bae12b90cc08a1edaf21ae6c6026a8dfc09a3c
Closes-Bug: #1580804
Partially-Implements: blueprint infra-driver-refactor

commit_message:
Clean up OpenEdge configuration

The OpenEdge cloud has been offline for five months, initially
disabled in I4e46c782a63279d9c18ff4ba2944c15b3027114b, so go ahead
and clean up lingering references. If it is restored later, this can
be reverted fairly easily.

Change-Id: I935d61b7101e221243a2d815b174b9b5a0eadb8c

subject: when we use smart card, we set boot_device to bios to wait agent to do something.But after agent finishes,we need to set boot_device to disk. If we do not do so，when ironic finishes deploy, node will boot to bois.

commit_message:
when we use smart card, we set boot_device to bios to wait agent to do something.But after agent finishes,we need to set boot_device to disk. If we do not do so，when ironic finishes deploy, node will boot to bois.

Change-Id: I1bda1fcce91e9e9b568b38182a0ada87875095b7

subject: probe: Use whole cycles in test_replication_servers_working
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-03-31 04:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-03-31 04:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I *think* this explains the failures on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/783981 ? Weird, though -- I feel like that ought to be a pretty narrow window.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-03-31 15:40:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The replicators are only stopped when everything is in sync, so it shouldn't matter when they are stopped within a cycle should it?

I wonder if the root cause is actually the 'random' do_listdir in the replicator update: on the test_node, the replicator run at line 180 in the test *may* get_hashes with do_listdir, which would cause the hashes.pkl on the test_node to change, so then replicator on another node *will* replicate objects to the test_node.

This hack will reproduce the test failure at line 188:

diff --git a/swift/obj/replicator.py b/swift/obj/replicator.py
index 7e753d545..9dabc509b 100644
--- a/swift/obj/replicator.py
+++ b/swift/obj/replicator.py
@@ -655,9 +655,7 @@ class ObjectReplicator(Daemon):
             hashed, local_hash = tpool.execute(
                 df_mgr._get_hashes, job['device'],
                 job['partition'], job['policy'],
-                do_listdir=_do_listdir(
-                    int(job['partition']),
-                    self.replication_cycle))
+                do_listdir=True)
             stats.suffix_hash += hashed
             self.logger.update_stats('suffix.hashes', hashed)
             attempts_left = len(job['nodes'])"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-03-31 22:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So at first I was thinking something like

 diff --git a/swift/obj/replicator.py b/swift/obj/replicator.py
 index f76121176..f9f2b415c 100644
 --- a/swift/obj/replicator.py
 +++ b/swift/obj/replicator.py
 @@ -473,6 +473,7 @@ class ObjectReplicator(Daemon):
          if success or not job['delete']:
              headers = dict(self.default_headers)
              headers['X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'] = int(job['policy'])
 +            time.sleep(5)
              with Timeout(self.http_timeout):
                  conn = http_connect(
                      node['replication_ip'], node['replication_port'],

could expose the race I was thinking of -- but it didn't, since we took out the whole partition tree, there was no hashes.invalid until the replicate call. Even something like

 diff --git a/swift/obj/diskfile.py b/swift/obj/diskfile.py
 index d738b66ce..e676902fe 100644
 --- a/swift/obj/diskfile.py
 +++ b/swift/obj/diskfile.py
 @@ -440,6 +440,7 @@ def invalidate_hash(suffix_dir):
      if not isinstance(suffix, bytes):
          suffix = suffix.encode('utf-8')
      with lock_path(partition_dir), open(invalidations_file, 'ab') as inv_fh:
 +        time.sleep(5)
          inv_fh.write(suffix + b"\n")
 
didn't do it, which surprised me a little. Eh -- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/784108 makes *way* more sense as a root cause; I'm content to abandon this.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-03-31 22:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Change-Id: Ifb3ad7c4794cab047aaf8cb95d915763755435ab
"}]
commit_message:
probe: Use whole cycles in test_replication_servers_working

Otherwise, there's a chance we kill the replicator between when rsync
has run and when the REPLICATE request has updated hashes.invalid.

Change-Id: Ifb3ad7c4794cab047aaf8cb95d915763755435ab

will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3f873bf0c7dc18bee32c591cfbbc50547cc8ccbc

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-23 20:10:05.000000000', 'message': 'Don't configure dnsmasq entries for "network" ports

Ports with device_owner like:
* floating_ip,
* DHCP,
* some types of router ports, like: HA interface interface,
* distributed ports,
don't need to be configured in the dnsmasq file.
So there is no need to reload dnsmasq every time when such port is
added/updated to the network.

This patch adds skip in such case which should improve load on the
Neutron DHCP agent.

Closes-Bug: #1913269
Change-Id: I63221507713b941c261cdf88781133149da8ab8d
(cherry picked from commit e4bbeee2060058d079885339e99ef7e6e366de16)

commit_message:
Don't configure dnsmasq entries for "network" ports

Ports with device_owner like:
* floating_ip,
* DHCP,
* some types of router ports, like: HA interface interface,
don't need to be configured in the dnsmasq file.
So there is no need to reload dnsmasq every time when such port is
added/updated to the network.

This patch adds skip in such case which should improve load on the
Neutron DHCP agent.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py

Closes-Bug: #1913269
Change-Id: I63221507713b941c261cdf88781133149da8ab8d
(cherry picked from commit e4bbeee2060058d079885339e99ef7e6e366de16)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-30 08:33:22.000000000', 'message': "Avoid fact gathering for group_by

There are a few places where we have a play with one task that uses the
group_by module to generate groups that are used in a subsequent play.
These plays do not need to gather facts for their target hosts.

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to
operate without access to remote hosts.

This change also adds changed_when: false to all group_by tasks, since
they show as changed but haven't really made any changes outside of
Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I18f67eda4e48058f3f402b9d0e692d6eeb02855f
(cherry picked from commit 388dfa369c9608f252dc946123c1801999931f6f)
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid fact gathering for group_by

There are a few places where we have a play with one task that uses the
group_by module to generate groups that are used in a subsequent play.
These plays do not need to gather facts for their target hosts.

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to
operate without access to remote hosts.

This change also adds changed_when: false to all group_by tasks, since
they show as changed but haven't really made any changes outside of
Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I18f67eda4e48058f3f402b9d0e692d6eeb02855f
(cherry picked from commit 388dfa369c9608f252dc946123c1801999931f6f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-18 13:57:09.000000000', 'message': "Fix incorrect ERROR status with IPv6 UDP members

Some IPv6 UDP members were incorrectly marked in ERROR status because of
a formatting issue between the keepalived configuration file and the
ipvsadm output. Both are used to compute the state of the members and
when a member's address contained '*:0:*', parsing was incorrect. Now
the health message generation function uses only the compressed IPv6
notation instead of mixing notations.

Story: 2008604
Task: 41783

Change-Id: I2fe94cd4c000f143c59c69e82d03c690acf5e0c3
(cherry picked from commit e5f9f6708c70313bd7e0c570f3541c0afb7fc09c)
(cherry picked from commit 8b210bb52a6c44b3bd69acdf2202d1625e763fb6)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect ERROR status with IPv6 UDP members

Some IPv6 UDP members were incorrectly marked in ERROR status because of
a formatting issue between the keepalived configuration file and the
ipvsadm output. Both are used to compute the state of the members and
when a member's address contained '*:0:*', parsing was incorrect. Now
the health message generation function uses only the compressed IPv6

commit_message:
Fix incorrect ERROR status with IPv6 UDP members

Some IPv6 UDP members were incorrectly marked in ERROR status because of
a formatting issue between the keepalived configuration file and the
ipvsadm output. Both are used to compute the state of the members and
when a member's address contained '*:0:*', parsing was incorrect. Now
the health message generation function uses only the compressed IPv6
notation instead of mixing notations.

Story: 2008604
Task: 41783

Change-Id: I2fe94cd4c000f143c59c69e82d03c690acf5e0c3
(cherry picked from commit e5f9f6708c70313bd7e0c570f3541c0afb7fc09c)

commit_message:
doc: Use a non-numerical anchor when referencing microversions

As called out in the review for
Ib7b9f4fd7673525129c03dc2943deedd0c7ad81f the use of a numerical anchor
causes a sequence id to be used that can change over time in the
document and thus is not stable to reference externally.

This change simply switches to a non-numerical anchor ensuring that
sphinx generates a stable anchor we can always reference.

Change-Id: I550f7fd89a13e58031b0ddfbcb4f6a5239dbf335

commit_message:
Schedule networks to new segments if needed

In case when subnet in segment X was created before hosts from
that segment was mapped in the Neutron DB, network wasn't scheduled
to the DHCP agents in that new segment.
Now DHCP scheduler is triggered in such case.

Closes-bug: #1917811
Change-Id: Ic9e64aa4ecdc3d56f00c26204ad931b810db7599
(cherry picked from commit 5c931f29132c3c5c01127f089f7d5909d2a19e4d)

subject: WIP: live migration: Pass limits onto scheduler-chosen destination
messages: [{'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2021-03-31 10:55:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-31 10:55:31.000000000', 'message': "WIP: live migration: Pass limits onto scheduler-chosen destination

If a live migration without a specific destination has been requested,
the conductor will get a list of potential destinations from the
scheduler. The conductor will then proceed to check if the destination
can accommodate the instance by calling check_can_live_migrate_destination.

However, this call is made in _find_destination by calling
_call_livem_checks_on_host, which will then remotely call the method
mentioned above, and passing it self.limits, which at that point is still None.

On the nova-compute side, check_can_live_migrate_destination will also create
the resource claim, which also includes the soon-to-used NUMA topology that
will be used by the live-migrated instance. For this, the function
numa_fit_instance_to_host is called, which will return the first match that
will fit the instance NUMA topology. This function will also receive those
limits from the conductor, and because it's always None, CPU and memory
allocation ratios are never respected for the NUMA node 0, so NUMA node 0
is always a valid candidate for Live Migrations, which means that with
every Live Migration the NUMA node 0 will get more and more overcommited,
eventually causing VMs to get into OOM as well.

This commit simply passes those limits received from the scheduler onto
nova-compute, so they can be used to make sure we don't overcommit NUMA nodes.
Those limits are created by the NUMATopologyFilter.

Change-Id: I6c585a34d6e774f890f992be647214e7e1073edb
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: live migration: Pass limits onto scheduler-chosen destination

If a live migration without a specific destination has been requested,
the conductor will get a list of potential destinations from the
scheduler. The conductor will then proceed to check if the destination
can accommodate the instance by calling check_can_live_migrate_destination.

However, this call is made in _find_destination by calling
_call_livem_checks_on_host, which will then remotely call the method
mentioned above, and passing it self.limits, which at that point is still None.

On the nova-compute side, check_can_live_migrate_destination will also create
the resource claim, which also includes the soon-to-used NUMA topology that
will be used by the live-migrated instance. For this, the function
numa_fit_instance_to_host is called, which will return the first match that
will fit the instance NUMA topology. This function will also receive those
limits from the conductor, and because it's always None, CPU and memory
allocation ratios are never respected for the NUMA node 0, so NUMA node 0
is always a valid candidate for Live Migrations, which means that with
every Live Migration the NUMA node 0 will get more and more overcommited,
eventually causing VMs to get into OOM as well.

This commit simply passes those limits received from the scheduler onto
nova-compute, so they can be used to make sure we don't overcommit NUMA nodes.
Those limits are created by the NUMATopologyFilter.

Change-Id: I6c585a34d6e774f890f992be647214e7e1073edb

commit_message:
Add support for vlan_limit option

This change introduces support for the vlan_limit option.
This parameter is currently set to 1 by default, but we should set
it to 2 to enable vlan_transparent, which requires nested vlans.

Related-Bug: #1918418
Change-Id: Id9aaab2a1e3ad2d2d43cd5cddf389d20abaf4461
(cherry picked from commit 4887f4ccd6e1031c3f4cc8fdbc17b77b4eecda0b)

We have (normally) 3 releases per cycle, please wait until the final one (should be done until Wednesday).'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 13:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello Ironic team,

Two patches are still missing [1][2] to allow us to branch Openstack requirements for Wallaby.

Those two patches are under the Ironic umbrella.

Few days ago Dimitry informed us on IRC that your team was late and that you will provide updates on Wednesday.

Please can you give us some visibility?

Requirements need to be branched [3] ASAP during R-2 [4].

We are waiting for your feedback.

Thanks by advance.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783675 (this one)
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783696
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/779832
[4] https://releases.openstack.org/reference/process.html#r-2-week'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2021-03-31 14:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2021-03-31 14:57:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-03-31 15:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 15:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Major version LGTM due to:

- https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/ironic-python-agent/unreleased.html#upgrade-notes
- https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/49d123dd6e32ea1455da1a2f11d6e624d435c308'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2021-03-31 16:21:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM:
* version bump looks OK
* approved by PTL
* test jobs logs don't show any issue"}]

commit_message:
Creating stable wallaby for ironic-python-agent

If you want to wait and make another release before the branch is cut,
someone from the team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that
patch to include another release and stable branch point.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday April 02.

Change-Id: I0835b299f3fe9d5ec383d482df76485c60f2aceb

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-12 18:34:18.000000000', 'message': 'Correct the contribution tallying for SIGs

There was a stray extra level of iteration over entries in the SIGs
repos file, causing them to get counted far, far more than once.
This had no impact on electoral roll generation as it only caused
contributions for some contributors to be over-counted, so did not
alter the list of contributors.

Change-Id: I9feafe4ecb1a8eadd4a95beb93f8c24a2a167610
'}]
commit_message:
Correct the contribution tallying for SIGs

There was a stray extra level of iteration over entries in the SIGs
repos file, causing them to get counted far, far more than once.
This had no impact on electoral roll generation as it only caused
contributions for some contributors to be over-counted, so did not
alter the list of contributors.

Change-Id: I9feafe4ecb1a8eadd4a95beb93f8c24a2a167610

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-31 06:45:15.000000000', 'message': "Move tmpwatch from cron.daily to actual root crontab

It appeary running the tmpwatch from the cron.daily location isn't
possible: the way cron/anacron is running things appears to break
SELinux context at some point, leading to SELinux denials caused by a
weird need for dac_override.

In order to NOT allow this dac_override (security hazard), and after
extensive testing, it seems it's better to push the job directly in
root's crontab.

Change-Id: Ib7e1d47fe7cffa2bd2ed1d72d94e4f380162f10a
Closes-Bug: #1922002
Resolves: rhbz#1944466
"}]
commit_message:
Move tmpwatch from cron.daily to actual root crontab

It appeary running the tmpwatch from the cron.daily location isn't
possible: the way cron/anacron is running things appears to break
SELinux context at some point, leading to SELinux denials caused by a
weird need for dac_override.

In order to NOT allow this dac_override (security hazard), and after
extensive testing, it seems it's better to push the job directly in
root's crontab.

Change-Id: Ib7e1d47fe7cffa2bd2ed1d72d94e4f380162f10a
Closes-Bug: #1922002
Resolves: rhbz#1944466

commit_message:
Add check for bootstrap_node for downcase

Downcase in puppet 6.14 throws an error if the input to it is Undef. We
can avoid this by checking for a value before trying to downcase.

See context https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/26297/
Closes-bug: #1905942

Change-Id: Ib2e97060523a4198a14949a15c9171b56928699c

Thanks for raising this! In https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-neutron-openvswitch/+/776754 we have moved trusty-mitaka to the dev_bundles, i.e. this isn't run by the CI system anymore as part of the full func test suite. It can be run manually by devs if needed, who will need to use "force_deploy" to get this working since we're removing trusty from the supported series. revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-30 09:27:35.000000000', 'message': 'Bumping min os-brick ver to 4.3.1

The os-brick 4.3.1 release fixes a critical data loss bug that can be
triggered by reconfiguring [libvirt]/volume_use_multipath while volumes
are attached.

The following requirements and lower-requirements are also bumped as
introduced into os-brick by Ie7dcc859e1291bd1d50b1ae516be38d8732de836:

    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on eventlet>=0.30.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.concurrency>=4.4.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.service>=2.5.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.serialization>=4.1.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.utils>=4.8.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on pbr>=5.5.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on requests>=2.25.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on tenacity>=6.3.1

Co-Authored-By: Lee Yarwood <lyarwood@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1921381
Change-Id: I0d5df271dec1c6035229b02ec45e03abad6f27e7
(cherry picked from commit e5b264bf7b28d3987b4ea30c61da4262aee7e4cd)
'}]
commit_message:
Bumping min os-brick ver to 4.3.1

The os-brick 4.3.1 release fixes a critical data loss bug that can be
triggered by reconfiguring [libvirt]/volume_use_multipath while volumes
are attached.

The following requirements and lower-requirements are also bumped as
introduced into os-brick by Ie7dcc859e1291bd1d50b1ae516be38d8732de836:

    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on eventlet>=0.30.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.concurrency>=4.4.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.service>=2.5.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.serialization>=4.1.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on oslo.utils>=4.8.0
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on pbr>=5.5.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on requests>=2.25.1
    os-brick 4.3.1 depends on tenacity>=6.3.1

Co-Authored-By: Lee Yarwood <lyarwood@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1921381
Change-Id: I0d5df271dec1c6035229b02ec45e03abad6f27e7
(cherry picked from commit e5b264bf7b28d3987b4ea30c61da4262aee7e4cd)

commit_message:
Move static-inventory option into parser group

Static-inventory should not be in extra_vars_group, this
patch move this option into parser.
It's faling when we want to provide both:
--static-inventory and --extra-vars option since the
extra_vars_group is mutually exclusive.

Change-Id: I973ea8c210db477b735a99755332346a646bea19

subject: Avoid PyPI ratelimit on roles retrieval retry
messages:
[{'account_id': 308, 'date': '2021-03-31 10:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 10:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2021-03-31 10:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Validator faced the following issue [1]:

  DEBUG: using sdist name as pypi-name 'ansible-role-atos-hsm'
  DEBUG: retrieving roles for 'ansible-role-atos-hsm'
  DEBUG: retrieving roles for 'ansible-role-atos-hsm'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/releases/.tox/validate/bin/validate-request", line 10, in <module>
[..]
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/xmlrpc/client.py", line 655, in close
    raise Fault(**self._stack[0])
xmlrpc.client.Fault: <Fault -32500: 'HTTPTooManyRequests: The action could not be performed because there were too many requests by the client. Limit may reset in 1 seconds.'>

By looking at the similar issue [2] this fix looks OK.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/f72a8875b48d4eef9b9f6f94ff5636c4/log/job-output.txt#4218-4219
[2] https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/8753'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2021-03-31 10:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 15:08:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Backuping some useful links here:
- https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/4321
- https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/8769'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-31 10:39:52.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid PyPI ratelimit on roles retrieval retry

When validating PyPI settings, we retrieve package roles. If that
retrieval is not successful on the first try, we immediately retry
with a canonicalized version of the package. This sometimes hits
PyPI ratelimits. This patch introduces a one second sleep to avoid
that error.

Change-Id: Ifd20200159a2f136827a1987606b650a6db5588f
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid PyPI ratelimit on roles retrieval retry

When validating PyPI settings, we retrieve package roles. If that
retrieval is not successful on the first try, we immediately retry
with a canonicalized version of the package. This sometimes hits
PyPI ratelimits. This patch introduces a one second sleep to avoid
that error.

Change-Id: Ifd20200159a2f136827a1987606b650a6db5588f

Hitachi: Trace REST API input/output logs

Trace REST API input/output to determine the cause when a problem
occurs.

commit_message:
Set external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings

For distributed vlan in ovn we need to add support of
creating mac addresses per compute and seting them in
external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings.

Conflicts:
	manifests/controller.pp
	spec/classes/ovn_controller_spec.rb

Backport note to Victoria:
Resolved conflicts caused by the enable_ovn_match_northd parameter[1]
which is not backported to Victoria.
 [1] 392ad7946ef5c7659f9320a3f832245e21f8365f

Backport note to Ussuri:
Resolved conflicts caused by the ovn_transport_zones parameter[2] which
is not backported to Ussuri.
 [2] dba349dad01edafab4a3fda3b9ad813cce814597

Related-Bug: #1881593
Co-Authored-By: Takashi Kajinami <tkajinam@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iddca7d8942bc52127525847f129eac8ea03934a1
(cherry picked from commit 73a1d569220d2601d9446838caaacea4168d5ac4)
(cherry picked from commit 490f7e56d25f1d3fc6997c313fe18d252252bc4d)
(cherry picked from commit 74d2389c2a14fa42416a87f88784c58d81144fd1)

commit_message:
Add support for always_set_cka_sensitive parameter

Some time ago BarbicanPkcs11AlwaysSetCkaSensitive option was
added to tripleo-heat-templates. change:
If3fa975e8243dfe30ef67ec81db891943a94a9d5

At the same time, it looks like relevant change was not added
to puppet-barbican project. This patch adds missing parameter
to barbican::plugins::p11_crypto class.

Backport note:
This backport includes the subsequent commit[1] which added
a unit test case for the new parameter.

 [1] d7e27eb854185ed3b28b07127cca7dbbb87f57b4

Partial-bug: #1916386
Change-Id: Idf9dc70cd68d4e594119efcd2a3c3a0e56621c96
(cherry picked from commit 27b1cc2735264556c372c7ea5d02f7164fdfcb68)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-30 09:21:50.000000000', 'message': "Avoid fact gathering for group_by

There are a few places where we have a play with one task that uses the
group_by module to generate groups that are used in a subsequent play.
These plays do not need to gather facts for their target hosts.

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to
operate without access to remote hosts.

This change also adds changed_when: false to all group_by tasks, since
they show as changed but haven't really made any changes outside of
Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I18f67eda4e48058f3f402b9d0e692d6eeb02855f
(cherry picked from commit 388dfa369c9608f252dc946123c1801999931f6f)
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid fact gathering for group_by

There are a few places where we have a play with one task that uses the
group_by module to generate groups that are used in a subsequent play.
These plays do not need to gather facts for their target hosts.

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to
operate without access to remote hosts.

This change also adds changed_when: false to all group_by tasks, since
they show as changed but haven't really made any changes outside of
Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I18f67eda4e48058f3f402b9d0e692d6eeb02855f
(cherry picked from commit 388dfa369c9608f252dc946123c1801999931f6f)

commit_message:
Set external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings

For distributed vlan in ovn we need to add support of
creating mac addresses per compute and seting them in
external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings.

Conflicts:
	manifests/controller.pp
	spec/classes/ovn_controller_spec.rb

Backport note to Victoria:
Resolved conflicts caused by the enable_ovn_match_northd parameter[1]
which is not backported to Victoria.
 [1] 392ad7946ef5c7659f9320a3f832245e21f8365f

Backport note to Ussuri:
Resolved conflicts caused by the ovn_transport_zones parameter[2] which
is not backported to Ussuri.
 [2] dba349dad01edafab4a3fda3b9ad813cce814597

Related-Bug: #1881593
Co-Authored-By: Takashi Kajinami <tkajinam@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iddca7d8942bc52127525847f129eac8ea03934a1
(cherry picked from commit 73a1d569220d2601d9446838caaacea4168d5ac4)
(cherry picked from commit 490f7e56d25f1d3fc6997c313fe18d252252bc4d)

commit_message:
Release note openstack-dashboard/use-internal-endpoints

Add an item for the openstack-dashboard charm. It gains
a new option (``use-internal-endpoints``) that affects
Horizon's connectivity with Keystone.

Change-Id: Ia697e40cd230084269c061e3895932a2ee19615b
Closes-Bug: #1812361

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-26 15:32:21.000000000', 'message': 'Add ipsec.secrets reload function to strongSwan driver

Currently, strongSwan driver only triggers "ipsec reload" command
when a new IPsec Site Connection configuration is received. If that
configuration uses a different PSK, it will not be picked up upon
reload called by restart() function. This change introduces a separate
reload_secrets() function which will call "ipsec rereadsecrets" before
"ipsec reload".

Closes-Bug: #1921514
Change-Id: Ia5458bbbb38b1d645547baf56ce3bb5ee2a97781
'}]
commit_message:
Add ipsec.secrets reload function to strongSwan driver

Currently, strongSwan driver only triggers "ipsec reload" command
when a new IPsec Site Connection configuration is received. If that
configuration uses a different PSK, it will not be picked up upon
reload called by restart() function. This change introduces a separate
reload_secrets() function which will call "ipsec rereadsecrets" before
"ipsec reload".

Closes-Bug: #1921514
Change-Id: Ia5458bbbb38b1d645547baf56ce3bb5ee2a97781

Add rule parameter in openstackclient

Add rule parameter in openstackclient as it was implemented in nova
microversion 2.64.  novaclient have it but not openstackclient.

subject: Use MultiKeyActionValue action for extra-[env-]vars arguments
messages:
[{'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2021-03-19 17:37:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2021-03-19 17:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-19 18:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

David, The arguments are good. 

They just have to be able to accept '{"VAR": "VALUE"}' AND VAR=VALUE format like Ansible does.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-20 21:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-20 21:22:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

WORKFLOW-1 due to some quick changes to make on the validations-libs side.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-21 07:17:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2021-03-21 12:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I did this review long time ago, which has been left unmerged, but the goal was the same but use the "narg" option:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/765137/3/tripleoclient/v1/tripleo_validator.py

Imho, it might be better to use it with narg instead of adding a deps on osc_lib for that.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 06:07:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1
> 
> I did this review long time ago, which has been left unmerged, but the goal was the same but use the "narg" option:
> https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/765137/3/tripleoclient/v1/tripleo_validator.py
> 
> Imho, it might be better to use it with narg instead of adding a deps on osc_lib for that.

We already depends on osc-lib! I don't see why we are not able to use some facilities coming from it? :/

By the way, neither this implementation nor yours will work fully. Especially when validations are waiting for a typed list variable. I would mean that the user will have to use the var file feature to do that when the vars are more complex and when they are simple, they will use the --extra-vars arguments. That should be documented somewhere because this makes the CLI not very clear to use at all.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 06:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> > Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > I did this review long time ago, which has been left unmerged, but the goal was the same but use the "narg" option:
> > https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/765137/3/tripleoclient/v1/tripleo_validator.py
> > 
> > Imho, it might be better to use it with narg instead of adding a deps on osc_lib for that.
> 
> We already depends on osc-lib! I don't see why we are not able to use some facilities coming from it? :/
> 
> By the way, neither this implementation nor yours will work fully. Especially when validations are waiting for a typed list variable. I would mean that the user will have to use the var file feature to do that when the vars are more complex and when they are simple, they will use the --extra-vars arguments. That should be documented somewhere because this makes the CLI not very clear to use at all.

Our intentions here should be clear and this must be reflected through the CLI helpers command:

Either:
1) --extra-vars should only be used to give simple data structure (KEY=VALUE) and the user will have to use --extra-vars-file to pass complex variables.

or:
2) --extra-vars should fully supported simple KEY=VALUE pairs and should also accept a dict for more complex data structure.

In both case, the --extra-vars helper will have to be fully documented.'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-03-22 06:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-03-22 07:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 07:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2021-03-22 07:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I know we already depend on osc_lib, but for the futur, I guess avoiding dependencies is better.

The narg way is doing the exact samevthing I think ?

My point is mainly that we are a layer on top of ansible-playbook, so I think we should handle the extra vars in a same way that Ansible does.'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-03-22 08:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 08:21:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> I know we already depend on osc_lib, but for the futur, I guess avoiding dependencies is better.
> 
> The narg way is doing the exact samevthing I think ?
> 
> My point is mainly that we are a layer on top of ansible-playbook, so I think we should handle the extra vars in a same way that Ansible does.

This CLI version is still fully depending on osc-lib while we don't have a unique CLI in validations-libs to replace this! And I think we should this kind of arguments parser actions in our future version.

This action allows us to use --extra-vars like this:
1) --extra-vars key1=value1,key2=value2,key3=value3[,keyx=valuex]
2) --extra-vars key1=value1 --extra-vars key2=value2 [--extra-vars keyx=valuex] 

This is almost what Ansible does. But here if we decide to just allow KEY=VALUE pair, user won't be able to pass more complex data structure and we have validations getting complex variables. That's why Ansible also allows to pass YAML/Json or a var file.

That's what I said earlier in a previous comment, both implementations are not covering everything!"}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 08:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-03-22 08:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-22 13:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-24 14:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-03-31 13:55:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Use MultiKeyActionValue action for extra-[env-]vars arguments

This patch adds the ability to pass extra variables and extra
environment variables to the Ansible execution as
key1=value1,key2=value2 instead of using a dict.

This action ensure that ``dest`` is a list. The list will finally
contain multiple dicts, with key=value pairs in them.

This patch also enables the Ansible execution verbosity when using a
different callback by passing --extra-env-vars
ANSIBLE_STDOUT_CALLBACK=default in the command line.

Finally, this change will make the CLI easier to use and faster to type.

Co-Authored-By: Gaël Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: David J. Peacock <dpeacock@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Icb1931d77ba5105d26ab38650f87d88f9397380f

commit_message:
Set external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings

For distributed vlan in ovn we need to add support of
creating mac addresses per compute and seting them in
external_ids:ovn-chassis-mac-mappings.

Conflicts:
	manifests/controller.pp
	spec/classes/ovn_controller_spec.rb

Backport note to Victoria:
Resolved conflicts caused by the enable_ovn_match_northd parameter[1]
which is not backported to Victoria.
 [1] 392ad7946ef5c7659f9320a3f832245e21f8365f

Related-Bug: #1881593
Co-Authored-By: Takashi Kajinami <tkajinam@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iddca7d8942bc52127525847f129eac8ea03934a1
(cherry picked from commit 73a1d569220d2601d9446838caaacea4168d5ac4)

commit_message:
Remove all skipped sc10 jobs in favor of smoke tests

https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/rdo-jobs/+/32279 moves the
tempest_test_whitelist regex to smoke tests in periodic. In
order to run this test, skipped jobs needs to be removed
otherwise tempest tests will fail with non regex found.

It needs to be skipped only on upstream not in periodic
and integration line.

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia7bff68f9fc9109eea7a988d86a0482da44797bd

rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I78450b3d1a3fd4b31daf63bb53bdced0b29af28c

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-06 15:49:54.000000000', 'message': "Test for disabling greendns

In commit 7c1d964faa we fixed how we disable greendns. This patch adds
a test for this. It also lays down the groundwork for future tests
of how we manage eventlet's monkeypatching.

How and what eventlet monkeypatches can be controlled by environment
variables that are processed by eventlet at import-time (for exmaple,
EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS). Nova manages all of this in nova.monkey_patch.
Therefore, nova.monkey_patch must be the first thing to import
eventlet. As nova.tests.functional.__init__ imports nova.monkey_patch,
our new test can go in the functional tree.

Related-bug: 1895322
Change-Id: I5b6c45b7b9a9eca3c13ecfaa5f50942922b69270
(cherry picked from commit 6f35e4fd2afdb8e26682fc5bd73dbe23236d25c7)
"}, {'created': '2020-11-19 14:59:27.000000000', 'message': "Test for disabling greendns

commit_message:
Test for disabling greendns

In commit 7c1d964faa we fixed how we disable greendns. This patch adds
a test for this. It also lays down the groundwork for future tests
of how we manage eventlet's monkeypatching.

How and what eventlet monkeypatches can be controlled by environment
variables that are processed by eventlet at import-time (for exmaple,
EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS). Nova manages all of this in nova.monkey_patch.
Therefore, nova.monkey_patch must be the first thing to import
eventlet. As nova.tests.functional.__init__ imports nova.monkey_patch,
our new test can go in the functional tree.

Related-bug: 1895322
Change-Id: I5b6c45b7b9a9eca3c13ecfaa5f50942922b69270
(cherry picked from commit 6f35e4fd2afdb8e26682fc5bd73dbe23236d25c7)
(cherry picked from commit 9ac794b93b827dde1d9545b88fd7913b7c00dacb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-29 13:37:21.000000000', 'message': "iSCSI: Fix flushing after multipath cfg change

OS-Brick disconnect_volume code assumes that the use_multipath parameter
that is used to instantiate the connector has the same value than the
connector that was used on the original connect_volume call.

Unfortunately this is not necessarily true, because Nova can attach a
volume, then its multipath configuration can be enabled or disabled, and
then a detach can be issued.

This leads to a series of serious issues such as:

- Not flushing the single path on disconnect_volume (possible data loss)
  and leaving it as a leftover device on the host when Nova calls
  terminate-connection on Cinder.

- Not flushing the multipath device (possible data loss) and leaving it
  as a leftover device similarly to the other case.

This patch changes how we do disconnects, now we assume we are always
disconnecting multipaths, and fallback to doing the single path
disconnect we used to do if we can't go that route.

The case when we cannot do a multipathed detach is mostly when we did
the connect as a single path and the Cinder driver doesn't provide
portal_targets and portal_iqns in the connection info for non
multipathed initialize-connection calls.

This changes introduces an additional call when working with single
paths (checking the discoverydb), but it should be an acceptable
trade-off to not lose data.

Closes-Bug: #1921381
Change-Id: I066d456fb1fe9159d4be50ffd8abf9a6d8d07901
(cherry picked from commit d4205bd0be60758d40e342d98424488d56e029ef)
(cherry picked from commit c70d70b24056b81a482de36a8e47757210e2e898)
"}, {'created': '2021-03-29 21:28:14.000000000', 'message': "iSCSI: Fix flushing after multipath cfg change

OS-Brick disconnect_volume code assumes that the use_multipath parameter
that is used to instantiate the connector has the same value than the
connector that was used on the original connect_volume call.

Unfortunately this is not necessarily true, because Nova can attach a
volume, then its multipath configuration can be enabled or disabled, and
then a detach can be issued.

This leads to a series of serious issues such as:

- Not flushing the single path on disconnect_volume (possible data loss)
  and leaving it as a leftover device on the host when Nova calls
  terminate-connection on Cinder.

- Not flushing the multipath device (possible data loss) and leaving it
  as a leftover device similarly to the other case.

This patch changes how we do disconnects, now we assume we are always
disconnecting multipaths, and fallback to doing the single path
disconnect we used to do if we can't go that route.

The case when we cannot do a multipathed detach is mostly when we did
the connect as a single path and the Cinder driver doesn't provide
portal_targets and portal_iqns in the connection info for non
multipathed initialize-connection calls.

This changes introduces an additional call when working with single
paths (checking the discoverydb), but it should be an acceptable
trade-off to not lose data.

Also includes squash to add release note from:
Add release note prelude for os-brick 4.4.0
Change-Id: I0f9e088fbb14ee9a73175aa31bca8c619db5a96f

Closes-Bug: #1921381
Change-Id: I066d456fb1fe9159d4be50ffd8abf9a6d8d07901
(cherry picked from commit d4205bd0be60758d40e342d98424488d56e029ef)
(cherry picked from commit c70d70b24056b81a482de36a8e47757210e2e898)
"}]
commit_message:
iSCSI: Fix flushing after multipath cfg change

OS-Brick disconnect_volume code assumes that the use_multipath parameter
that is used to instantiate the connector has the same value than the
connector that was used on the original connect_volume call.

Unfortunately this is not necessarily true, because Nova can attach a
volume, then its multipath configuration can be enabled or disabled, and
then a detach can be issued.

This leads to a series of serious issues such as:

- Not flushing the single path on disconnect_volume (possible data loss)
  and leaving it as a leftover device on the host when Nova calls
  terminate-connection on Cinder.

- Not flushing the multipath device (possible data loss) and leaving it
  as a leftover device similarly to the other case.

This patch changes how we do disconnects, now we assume we are always
disconnecting multipaths, and fallback to doing the single path
disconnect we used to do if we can't go that route.

The case when we cannot do a multipathed detach is mostly when we did
the connect as a single path and the Cinder driver doesn't provide
portal_targets and portal_iqns in the connection info for non
multipathed initialize-connection calls.

This changes introduces an additional call when working with single
paths (checking the discoverydb), but it should be an acceptable
trade-off to not lose data.

Also includes squash to add release note from:
Add release note prelude for os-brick 4.4.0
Change-Id: I0f9e088fbb14ee9a73175aa31bca8c619db5a96f

Closes-Bug: #1921381
Change-Id: I066d456fb1fe9159d4be50ffd8abf9a6d8d07901
(cherry picked from commit d4205bd0be60758d40e342d98424488d56e029ef)
(cherry picked from commit c70d70b24056b81a482de36a8e47757210e2e898)

commit_message:
Extend ansible inventory from network config file

Some node network_config options defined in the baremetal
deployment yaml definition can't be stored on neutron resources
as tags, because tag strings has a limited max lenght.

In the triple-ansible change https://review.opendev.org/772766
the baremetal deployment workflow put's this data into a config
file. With this change the config in the file source is merged
into the generated ansible inventory.

Partial-Implements: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: I1e339acb21d2acb1c336420af9f04d01f861aa91

ctlplane_subnet_cidr is already set in tripleo-heat-templates by the {{role.name}}GroupVars resource. Do we need both?'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-05 23:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> ctlplane_subnet_cidr is already set in tripleo-heat-templates by the {{role.name}}GroupVars resource. Do we need both?

The goal is to have enough information in the inventory to run the tripleo_network_config ansible role which applies node network configuration prior to creating the heat stack.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-03-08 15:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-09 15:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-09 15:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-03-15 22:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> > Patch Set 7:
> > 
> > ctlplane_subnet_cidr is already set in tripleo-heat-templates by the {{role.name}}GroupVars resource. Do we need both?
> 
> The goal is to have enough information in the inventory to run the tripleo_network_config ansible role which applies node network configuration prior to creating the heat stack.

how would this be used when there is no neutron then? how would the needed network information get populated in the inventory if it is all presently set in the Heat stack via parameter values?'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-16 16:36:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1
> 
> > Patch Set 7:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 7:
> > > 
> > > ctlplane_subnet_cidr is already set in tripleo-heat-templates by the {{role.name}}GroupVars resource. Do we need both?
> > 
> > The goal is to have enough information in the inventory to run the tripleo_network_config ansible role which applies node network configuration prior to creating the heat stack.
> 
> how would this be used when there is no neutron then? how would the needed network information get populated in the inventory if it is all presently set in the Heat stack via parameter values?

This wouldn't work if there is no neutron. This is using data stored in neutron to generate the inventory. You'd have to have another thing generate the inventory, as in type it up manually or invent your own tool/ipam.

If we want to separate the network configuration from the stack, we can't rely on heat stack parameter values or heat stack output at all. So heat stack parameter values are replaced by the network file definition and the baremetal deployment definition.

I put a doc's patch up, it might help to get better understanding on the UX changes: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/779355/1/deploy-guide/source/provisioning/baremetal_provision.rst"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-03-16 21:06:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > > Patch Set 7:
> > > 
> > > > Patch Set 7:
> > > > 
> > > > ctlplane_subnet_cidr is already set in tripleo-heat-templates by the {{role.name}}GroupVars resource. Do we need both?
> > > 
> > > The goal is to have enough information in the inventory to run the tripleo_network_config ansible role which applies node network configuration prior to creating the heat stack.
> > 
> > how would this be used when there is no neutron then? how would the needed network information get populated in the inventory if it is all presently set in the Heat stack via parameter values?
> 
> This wouldn't work if there is no neutron. This is using data stored in neutron to generate the inventory. You'd have to have another thing generate the inventory, as in type it up manually or invent your own tool/ipam.
> 
> If we want to separate the network configuration from the stack, we can't rely on heat stack parameter values or heat stack output at all. So heat stack parameter values are replaced by the network file definition and the baremetal deployment definition.
> 
> I put a doc's patch up, it might help to get better understanding on the UX changes: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/779355/1/deploy-guide/source/provisioning/baremetal_provision.rst

What I'm missing is how this information gets into the inventory if there is no neutron.

We're saying that os-net-config is now run before the Heat stack. So, as a user with an already deployed cloud I have to write a new baremetal yaml config with all the new ways to set fixed ip's, etc.

Assuming that was done, how would that data flow from the baremetal yaml into the inventory if there is no neutron? This is something that works today, we don't need neutron if not using Ironic, so I just want to make sure that will still work. Today, Heat takes care of transforming the input data into the format for os-net-config. What will do that in the new way, assuming no Neutron, and no Heat stack (yet)."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-17 04:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> What I'm missing is how this information gets into the inventory if there is no neutron.
> 
> We're saying that os-net-config is now run before the Heat stack. So, as a user with an already deployed cloud I have to write a new baremetal yaml config with all the new ways to set fixed ip's, etc.
> 
> Assuming that was done, how would that data flow from the baremetal yaml into the inventory if there is no neutron? This is something that works today, we don't need neutron if not using Ironic, so I just want to make sure that will still work. Today, Heat takes care of transforming the input data into the format for os-net-config. What will do that in the new way, assuming no Neutron, and no Heat stack (yet).

This work doesn't aim for a no neutron scenario, the "overcloud node provision" command assumes neutron is present and network/segment/subnet neutron API resources are present.

If you don't have neutron you would have to:

1. Deploy server manually
2. Type up your the following files:
* overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml - DeployedServerPortMap, NodePortMap, HostnameMap
  See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/70/767070/8/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/9a20a17/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-baremetal-deployed.yaml.txt.gz
* overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml - DeployedNetworkEnvironment, i.e input for THT/network/deployed_networks.yaml
  See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml.txt.gz
* overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml - ControlPlaneVipData, VipPortMap
  See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml.txt.gz
3. Deploy the heat stack with:

  overcloud deploy overcloud \
   --stack-only \
   --deployed-server \
   -r roles-file.yaml \
   -n networks-file.yaml \
   -e overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml \
   -e overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml \
   -e overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml

.. NOTE: You could opt to use "from_pool" environments for ports and then not add NodePortMap in overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml, i.e use different values for OS::TripleO::<role>::Ports::<network>Port resource registry entries.

4. Generate Ansible inventory (This will need the stack output since there is no neutron, so I guess ephemeral heat workflow will have to do this)
5. Run the tripleo_network_config ansible role using the inventory to apply network configuration to the pre-deployed nodes:

  ansible-playbook -i <inventory> tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-node-network-config.yaml'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-17 05:19:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9: Patch Set 8 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-17 08:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck ( Not found image: http://10.4.70.199:5001/v2/tripleomaster/openstack-mariadb/manifests/3616cbd988a2085bd721226e90d58b88", "params": {}, "success": false} )'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-03-17 20:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> This work doesn't aim for a no neutron scenario, the "overcloud node provision" command assumes neutron is present and network/segment/subnet neutron API resources are present.

This presently works today without neutron, so we need to make sure it will continue to work.

> 
> If you don't have neutron you would have to:
> 
> 1. Deploy server manually
> 2. Type up your the following files:
> * overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml - DeployedServerPortMap, NodePortMap, HostnameMap

This is fine to require. As you say below, we can still use the from_pool ports and use the <Role>IPs parameters instead of NodePortMap.

> * overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml - DeployedNetworkEnvironment, i.e input for THT/network/deployed_networks.yaml
>   See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml.txt.gz

Having to create this one manually seems unnecessary as we already have network_data.yaml, and/or the parameter values. Could the new commands generate DeployedNetworkEnvironment without neutron? I don't think this should be required.

> * overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml - ControlPlaneVipData, VipPortMap
>   See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml.txt.gz

This is fine. There are other ways to set these today, but I'm ok with the change.

> 3. Deploy the heat stack with:
> 
>   overcloud deploy overcloud \
>    --stack-only \
>    --deployed-server \
>    -r roles-file.yaml \
>    -n networks-file.yaml \
>    -e overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml \
>    -e overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml \
>    -e overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml
> 
> .. NOTE: You could opt to use "from_pool" environments for ports and then not add NodePortMap in overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml, i.e use different values for OS::TripleO::<role>::Ports::<network>Port resource registry entries.
> 
> 4. Generate Ansible inventory (This will need the stack output since there is no neutron, so I guess ephemeral heat workflow will have to do this)

Our current deployment flow already generates the ansible inventory (no matter what type of Heat is used, or the presence of Neutron).

> 5. Run the tripleo_network_config ansible role using the inventory to apply network configuration to the pre-deployed nodes:
> 
>   ansible-playbook -i <inventory> tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-node-network-config.yaml

We shouldn't require this as a manual step. Are you saying that the NetworkConfig tasks that run os-net-config will get removed from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml?'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-17 22:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> Patch Set 9:
> 
> > This work doesn't aim for a no neutron scenario, the "overcloud node provision" command assumes neutron is present and network/segment/subnet neutron API resources are present.
> 
> This presently works today without neutron, so we need to make sure it will continue to work.
> 

How does this work without neutron today?

I see several places in the code which expect data from the network resources.
https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L559
 ... many more ... this section is full of deps:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L1045-L1087

Many of the above are fairly new (i.e Victoria), but even in queens we rely on getting the net_cidr_map of the Networks resource: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/stable/queens/overcloud.j2.yaml#L349

I'm not aware of any other "deployed_network" resource overriding these?

I can see how we can use from_pool, and deployed_neutron_port resources to not create any port resources in neutron. But if you don't enable network-isolation, i.e leave all networks mapped to OS::Heat::None there is a lot of ansible vars that are not populated, and the net_cidr_map would not contain the right data.

> > 
> > If you don't have neutron you would have to:
> > 
> > 1. Deploy server manually
> > 2. Type up your the following files:
> > * overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml - DeployedServerPortMap, NodePortMap, HostnameMap
> 
> This is fine to require. As you say below, we can still use the from_pool ports and use the <Role>IPs parameters instead of NodePortMap.
> 
> > * overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml - DeployedNetworkEnvironment, i.e input for THT/network/deployed_networks.yaml
> >   See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml.txt.gz
> 
> Having to create this one manually seems unnecessary as we already have network_data.yaml, and/or the parameter values. Could the new commands generate DeployedNetworkEnvironment without neutron? I don't think this should be required.
> 

Creating DeployedNetworkEnvironment from network_data.yaml is certainly possible, but there is no implementation.

None of the specs being implemented is touching a 'no neutron' scenario:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2.html
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2-node-ports.html

I consider this out of scope.

> > * overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml - ControlPlaneVipData, VipPortMap
> >   See example: https://logserver.rdoproject.org/28/779828/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/d332269/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml.txt.gz
> 
> This is fine. There are other ways to set these today, but I'm ok with the change.
> 
> > 3. Deploy the heat stack with:
> > 
> >   overcloud deploy overcloud \
> >    --stack-only \
> >    --deployed-server \
> >    -r roles-file.yaml \
> >    -n networks-file.yaml \
> >    -e overcloud-networks-deployed.yaml \
> >    -e overcloud-vips-deployed.yaml \
> >    -e overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml
> > 
> > .. NOTE: You could opt to use "from_pool" environments for ports and then not add NodePortMap in overcloud-servers-deployed.yaml, i.e use different values for OS::TripleO::<role>::Ports::<network>Port resource registry entries.
> > 
> > 4. Generate Ansible inventory (This will need the stack output since there is no neutron, so I guess ephemeral heat workflow will have to do this)
> 
> Our current deployment flow already generates the ansible inventory (no matter what type of Heat is used, or the presence of Neutron).
> 
> > 5. Run the tripleo_network_config ansible role using the inventory to apply network configuration to the pre-deployed nodes:
> > 
> >   ansible-playbook -i <inventory> tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-node-network-config.yaml
> 
> We shouldn't require this as a manual step. Are you saying that the NetworkConfig tasks that run os-net-config will get removed from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml?

What I hear from DF is a wish to decouple node network configuration from the "deployment", i.e its done separate step that ideally can be changed without re-deploying. This would mean removing the steps from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml. (I'm not saying this shouldn't be discussed further, changing the node network config without also re-configuring deployed services to mirror the changes will not always be possible).'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-18 07:08:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-03-18 13:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> How does this work without neutron today?
> 
> I see several places in the code which expect data from the network resources.
> https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L559
>  ... many more ... this section is full of deps:
> https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L1045-L1087
> 
> Many of the above are fairly new (i.e Victoria), but even in queens we rely on getting the net_cidr_map of the Networks resource: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/stable/queens/overcloud.j2.yaml#L349
> 
> I'm not aware of any other "deployed_network" resource overriding these?
> 
> I can see how we can use from_pool, and deployed_neutron_port resources to not create any port resources in neutron. But if you don't enable network-isolation, i.e leave all networks mapped to OS::Heat::None there is a lot of ansible vars that are not populated, and the net_cidr_map would not contain the right data.

I'm not sure I fully understand the reasoning, but feel free to ping me, and I can show you some examples. We don't require network-isolation today, so things certainly work when networks are mapped to OS::Heat::None (which implies Neutron is not creating those networks).

There are cases where we do enable network-isolation, but do not create network resources in the stacks. See the use of ManageNetworks. In that case, the network properties needed to create Heat/ansible values are read directly from network_data.yaml (and possibly the generated parameters, not sure, but the parameters just default to the network_data.yaml values anyway).

Further, we can remap any resource (Neutron or custom) to a template resource as long as it provides the correct interface.

We have deployed with network-isolation and various nic configs with "openstack tripleo deploy" which uses the ephemeral heat-all, which has no endpoint catalog, no keystone, and of course no Neutron interaction. The currently under development director operator is doing exactly that.


> > Having to create this one manually seems unnecessary as we already have network_data.yaml, and/or the parameter values. Could the new commands generate DeployedNetworkEnvironment without neutron? I don't think this should be required.
> > 
> 
> Creating DeployedNetworkEnvironment from network_data.yaml is certainly possible, but there is no implementation.

I'm not in favor of the additional manual steps. We already have the user enter all the needed data in network_data.yaml. An additional environment shouldn't be necessary which just (re)formats network_data.yaml into a Heat environment.

> 
> None of the specs being implemented is touching a 'no neutron' scenario:
> https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2.html
> https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2-node-ports.html
> 
> I consider this out of scope.

That's ok (I think). As long as the changes don't break what is already in scope in TripleO. This patch is taking things in a direction which had me asking how it would work w/o Neutron.

> > We shouldn't require this as a manual step. Are you saying that the NetworkConfig tasks that run os-net-config will get removed from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml?
> 
> What I hear from DF is a wish to decouple node network configuration from the "deployment", i.e its done separate step that ideally can be changed without re-deploying. This would mean removing the steps from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml. (I'm not saying this shouldn't be discussed further, changing the node network config without also re-configuring deployed services to mirror the changes will not always be possible).

I'm fine with changing ordering and the decoupling, I support that. But it still needs to happen within the "openstack overcloud deploy" command. Separate commands might be ok, I'd want to see what the model would look like. For example, if we changed the expectation that "overcloud deploy" can do everything to a requirement that you must run:

overcloud node provision
overcloud node provision --ports --networks (whatever...)
overcloud node network config (again, whatever we call it)
overcloud deploy

I might be ok with that, although it would break a lot of existing automation. What I'm not in favor of though is a model where we ask the user to conditionally write an ansible inventory and manually run ansible-playbook if they have chosen to use other features.

I'm not speaking for the whole DF, but decoupling Neutron management always made sense to me, node network configuration not so much. The network configuration actually seems very tightly dependent on the software configuration (as you say). We even have provided interfaces that allow for software configuration *before* network config via os-net-config is done, things like 
kernel params and needed nfv configs, things that need to be configured before interfaces are configured and brought up.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-18 15:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> Patch Set 9:
> 
> > How does this work without neutron today?
> > 
> > I see several places in the code which expect data from the network resources.
> > https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L559
> >  ... many more ... this section is full of deps:
> > https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L1045-L1087
