> > Many of the above are fairly new (i.e Victoria), but even in queens we rely on getting the net_cidr_map of the Networks resource: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/stable/queens/overcloud.j2.yaml#L349
> > 
> > I'm not aware of any other "deployed_network" resource overriding these?
> > 
> > I can see how we can use from_pool, and deployed_neutron_port resources to not create any port resources in neutron. But if you don't enable network-isolation, i.e leave all networks mapped to OS::Heat::None there is a lot of ansible vars that are not populated, and the net_cidr_map would not contain the right data.
> 
> I'm not sure I fully understand the reasoning, but feel free to ping me, and I can show you some examples. We don't require network-isolation today, so things certainly work when networks are mapped to OS::Heat::None (which implies Neutron is not creating those networks).
> 
> There are cases where we do enable network-isolation, but do not create network resources in the stacks. See the use of ManageNetworks. In that case, the network properties needed to create Heat/ansible values are read directly from network_data.yaml (and possibly the generated parameters, not sure, but the parameters just default to the network_data.yaml values anyway).
> 

In the case of ManageNetworks, the output value for `network_cidrs`[1] will not contain the correct information, in the extension `net_cidr_map`[2] will be incorrect. The following services depend on the correct `net_cidr_map` map value to configure the service:

  deployment/snmp/snmp-baremetal-puppet.yaml
  deployment/apache/apache-baremetal-puppet.j2.yaml
  deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-rgw.yaml
  deployment/experimental/designate/designate-worker-container-puppet.yaml
  deployment/memcached/memcached-container-puppet.yaml
  deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml

I always assumed you had some special way to extract that from the parent stack, in the multistack scenario? If there isn't I don't think things are actually configured correctly.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/d58efb58e0c39b2ca1585d87fe6d542484b33ad0/network/network.j2#L247
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/d58efb58e0c39b2ca1585d87fe6d542484b33ad0/network/networks.j2.yaml#L22




> Further, we can remap any resource (Neutron or custom) to a template resource as long as it provides the correct interface.
> 

You still can, the only interface I am aware of breaking is the service VIPs for redis and ovn_dbs.


> We have deployed with network-isolation and various nic configs with "openstack tripleo deploy" which uses the ephemeral heat-all, which has no endpoint catalog, no keystone, and of course no Neutron interaction. The currently under development director operator is doing exactly that.
> 
> 
> > > Having to create this one manually seems unnecessary as we already have network_data.yaml, and/or the parameter values. Could the new commands generate DeployedNetworkEnvironment without neutron? I don't think this should be required.
> > > 
> > 
> > Creating DeployedNetworkEnvironment from network_data.yaml is certainly possible, but there is no implementation.
> 
> I'm not in favor of the additional manual steps. We already have the user enter all the needed data in network_data.yaml. An additional environment shouldn't be necessary which just (re)formats network_data.yaml into a Heat environment.
> 
> > 
> > None of the specs being implemented is touching a 'no neutron' scenario:
> > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2.html
> > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/triplo-network-data-v2-node-ports.html
> > 
> > I consider this out of scope.
> 
> That's ok (I think). As long as the changes don't break what is already in scope in TripleO. This patch is taking things in a direction which had me asking how it would work w/o Neutron.
> 

This patch is still populating the environment with data from the heat stack, unless it found a value in neutron first. So when there is no neutron it's all from the stack, just like before.


> > > We shouldn't require this as a manual step. Are you saying that the NetworkConfig tasks that run os-net-config will get removed from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml?
> > 
> > What I hear from DF is a wish to decouple node network configuration from the "deployment", i.e its done separate step that ideally can be changed without re-deploying. This would mean removing the steps from deploy_steps_playbook.yaml. (I'm not saying this shouldn't be discussed further, changing the node network config without also re-configuring deployed services to mirror the changes will not always be possible).
> 
> I'm fine with changing ordering and the decoupling, I support that. But it still needs to happen within the "openstack overcloud deploy" command. Separate commands might be ok, I'd want to see what the model would look like. For example, if we changed the expectation that "overcloud deploy" can do everything to a requirement that you must run:
> 
> overcloud node provision
> overcloud node provision --ports --networks (whatever...)
> overcloud node network config (again, whatever we call it)
> overcloud deploy
> 

I agree, the multiple commands is'nt ideal. Some people seem to like this, and other don't, including me. What I want to do is similar to what this patch does for baremetal provisioning:
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/69aad030d3e1808826ddda37ab47290d1925b6fe

So the full deployment can be done with:
overcloud deploy [..] --baremetal-deployment --network-deployment --vip-deployment [..]

> I might be ok with that, although it would break a lot of existing automation. What I'm not in favor of though is a model where we ask the user to conditionally write an ansible inventory and manually run ansible-playbook if they have chosen to use other features.
> 
> I'm not speaking for the whole DF, but decoupling Neutron management always made sense to me, node network configuration not so much. The network configuration actually seems very tightly dependent on the software configuration (as you say). We even have provided interfaces that allow for software configuration *before* network config via os-net-config is done, things like 
> kernel params and needed nfv configs, things that need to be configured before interfaces are configured and brought up.

 ... indeed these are valid arguments.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-18 17:18:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

In that case, the network properties needed to create Heat/ansible values are read directly from network_data.yaml (and possibly the generated parameters, not sure, but the parameters just default to the network_data.yaml values anyway).
> > 
> 
> In the case of ManageNetworks, the output value for `network_cidrs`[1] will not contain the correct information, in the extension `net_cidr_map`[2] will be incorrect. The following services depend on the correct `net_cidr_map` map value to configure the service:
> 
>   deployment/snmp/snmp-baremetal-puppet.yaml
>   deployment/apache/apache-baremetal-puppet.j2.yaml
>   deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-rgw.yaml
>   deployment/experimental/designate/designate-worker-container-puppet.yaml
>   deployment/memcached/memcached-container-puppet.yaml
>   deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml
> 
> I always assumed you had some special way to extract that from the parent stack, in the multistack scenario? If there isn't I don't think things are actually configured correctly.
> 
> [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/d58efb58e0c39b2ca1585d87fe6d542484b33ad0/network/network.j2#L247
> [2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/d58efb58e0c39b2ca1585d87fe6d542484b33ad0/network/networks.j2.yaml#L22
> 

After discussin on IRC I see this is My bad, there is a condition[1] when creating output for network resources that cover the `net_cidr_map` case that I have overlooked. Unfortunately we most likely broke this usecase in Victoria, mainly with change[2].

I've filed bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1920050


I don't think there is any reason blocking this patch.


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/network/network.j2#L280-L281
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/5b3878580a9768be7c7c39d3062f567eb5e13767"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-03-23 11:34:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

i think we can move forward with this one as long as:

- there is a way to populate this data for pre-provisioned nodes (Heat for now)
- we maintain existing network configuration as part of the config-download playbooks as the default for now'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-03-30 13:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-30 13:32:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> Patch Set 9: -Code-Review
> 
> i think we can move forward with this one as long as:
> 
> - there is a way to populate this data for pre-provisioned nodes (Heat for now)

There is Heat, and also the option to use 'overcloud node provision' command with nodes defined as 'unmanaged' in the baremetal yaml. When using 'overcloud node provision' command with unmanaged nodes defined there will be no metalsmith/ironic provisioning, but the neutron api resources will be created, so that the inventory can be created using neutron as a source.

> - we maintain existing network configuration as part of the config-download playbooks as the default for now

Agreed, we need to keep it at-least until we have an interface for users to apply pre-network configuration."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-03-31 08:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Extend network info in generated inventory

When building the inventory from neutron resources,
set network related role_vars in the generated
ansible inventory. The following vars are set:

  {{ network_name }}_cidr
  {{ network_name }}_dns_nameservers
  {{ network_name }}_gateway_ip
  {{ network_name }}_host_routes
  {{ network_name }}_mtu
  {{ network_name }}_vlan_id
  ctlplane_subnet_cidr
  networks_all
  networks_lower
  role_networks

Partial-Implements: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: I3072895b44845736050255fb0b6d5f0bdd5c5f48

commit_message:
Collect nested virtualization info

We run our deployment on multiple cloud, it is good to
collect nested virt info in order to investigate
server creation related issue.

It is needed for sc10 kvm jobs which is still in
development here:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/q/topic:%22fix_octavia_kvm%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ib9d89c9ce0e889a7ee6250f66b55c99a245d6d00

commit_message:
Release manila-tempest-plugin for wallaby

This is the automatic release for manila-tempest-plugin.
Please +1 if this is ready to go, or -1 if the team needs a little more
time. If so, please update with the new commit hash to use when ready.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 1.3.0..f083c71
f083c71 Add create share from snapshot in CephFS
170e800 Added test_create_access_rule_cephx_admin_user testcase
d00bed4 Harden manage negative tests

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5c07815eb408e836552d8befabb9601682a7d3c5

of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while
other containers are not ready yet. Thus we should be creating backends
at the very end of the deployment, when all containers are set.

'}]
commit_message:
Fix condition when to create backends

Backend creation should happen on the last host in the group, instead
of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while
other containers are not ready yet. Thus we should be creating backends
at the very end of the deployment, when all containers are set.

Change-Id: I3d5811e059d1b5cb3e87fe7657872e41105c832e
Closes-Bug: #1920964
(cherry picked from commit 91fef6b5cc08d65e0c21b998595f4e74b74c3248)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-22 11:12:29.000000000', 'message': "Introduce tox-ansible to tripleo-validations

This patch adds basic configuration for tox-ansible[1].

Tox-ansible is a plugin for tox which auto-generates tox environments
for running quality assurance tools like ansible-test or molecule. This
tool is rather tightly integrated for the official Molecule testing tool
that integrates with Ansible.

At first, it will allow us to list very quickly all the Ansible Molecule
tests for each roles with their scenario(s):

Example:

    $ tox -l
    ...
    roles-ceph-ceph-ansible-installed
    roles-ceph-default
    roles-check_kernel_version-default
    roles-check_network_gateway-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-rhsm_mismatch
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-config_OK
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-default
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_drivers
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_params
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-required_missing
    ...

However, we won't be able to execute them as it for now without to make
some small manual modifications in the molecule.yml file first before to
execute them. This will be covered as soon as possible in a following-patch.

[1] - https://github.com/ansible-community/tox-ansible

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia1606db814f37a11e48508139b90cdd43c083f6b
(cherry picked from commit edb1ad92101d11a0d485eb3bbb05052e3daaeb21)
"}]
commit_message:
Introduce tox-ansible to tripleo-validations

This patch adds basic configuration for tox-ansible[1].

Tox-ansible is a plugin for tox which auto-generates tox environments
for running quality assurance tools like ansible-test or molecule. This
tool is rather tightly integrated for the official Molecule testing tool
that integrates with Ansible.

At first, it will allow us to list very quickly all the Ansible Molecule
tests for each roles with their scenario(s):

Example:

    $ tox -l
    ...
    roles-ceph-ceph-ansible-installed
    roles-ceph-default
    roles-check_kernel_version-default
    roles-check_network_gateway-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-rhsm_mismatch
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-config_OK
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-default
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_drivers
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_params
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-required_missing
    ...

However, we won't be able to execute them as it for now without to make
some small manual modifications in the molecule.yml file first before to
execute them. This will be covered as soon as possible in a following-patch.

[1] - https://github.com/ansible-community/tox-ansible

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia1606db814f37a11e48508139b90cdd43c083f6b
(cherry picked from commit edb1ad92101d11a0d485eb3bbb05052e3daaeb21)

commit_message:
Remove neutron-l3-compute-dvr referenced nowhere

deployment/neutron/neutron-l3-compute-dvr.yaml has no references
in tht, and also it points the baremetal puppet configuration.
We only support it containerized.

Change-Id: Idc40c2320ba3d9643d2430150238a72d3775a1b0
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-01 16:01:02.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Use specific user when probing encrypted rbd disks during extend

I0c3f14100a18107f7e416293f3d4fcc641ce5e55 introduced new logic when
extending LUKSv1 encrypted rbd volumes. As part of this qemu-img is used
to probe the rbd volume to determine the size of the LUKSv1 header.

The URI used to point to the rbd volume did not provide a user and
assumed that n-cpu/privsep would have access to the admin keyring. This
isn't always the case in most environments and would result in a failure
to probe the disk when the admin keyring wasn't available.

This change resolves this by appending the `id:$username` option to the
end of the URI provided to qemu-img using the `auth_username` found in
the connection_info from Cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1913575
Change-Id: Ia6d6dcdd7042f2aef6b3abeb5cd0f7525678a3b7
(cherry picked from commit b62a1abd616cea7fdfcad18e1cf548767d67b6dd)
(cherry picked from commit 5d1adb2604de37ad6717a604b87d9fbaf35f0999)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Use specific user when probing encrypted rbd disks during extend

I0c3f14100a18107f7e416293f3d4fcc641ce5e55 introduced new logic when
extending LUKSv1 encrypted rbd volumes. As part of this qemu-img is used
to probe the rbd volume to determine the size of the LUKSv1 header.

The URI used to point to the rbd volume did not provide a user and
assumed that n-cpu/privsep would have access to the admin keyring. This
isn't always the case in most environments and would result in a failure
to probe the disk when the admin keyring wasn't available.

This change resolves this by appending the `id:$username` option to the
end of the URI provided to qemu-img using the `auth_username` found in
the connection_info from Cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1913575
Change-Id: Ia6d6dcdd7042f2aef6b3abeb5cd0f7525678a3b7
(cherry picked from commit b62a1abd616cea7fdfcad18e1cf548767d67b6dd)
(cherry picked from commit 5d1adb2604de37ad6717a604b87d9fbaf35f0999)

Make _rebase_with_qemu_img() generic

Move volume_delete related logic away from this method, in order to make
it generic and usable elsewhere.

[{'created': '2020-10-09 11:58:42.000000000', 'message': 'Use absolute path during qemu img rebase

During an assisted volume snapshot delete request from Cinder nova
removes the snapshot from the backing file chain. During that nova
checks the existence of such file. However in some cases (see the bug
report) the path is relative and therefore os.path.exists fails.

This patch makes sure that nova uses the volume absolute path to make
the backing file path absolute as well.

Closes-Bug #1885528

Change-Id: I58dca95251b607eaff602783fee2fc38e2421944

commit_message:
Use absolute path during qemu img rebase

During an assisted volume snapshot delete request from Cinder nova
removes the snapshot from the backing file chain. During that nova
checks the existence of such file. However in some cases (see the bug
report) the path is relative and therefore os.path.exists fails.

This patch makes sure that nova uses the volume absolute path to make
the backing file path absolute as well.

Closes-Bug #1885528

Change-Id: I58dca95251b607eaff602783fee2fc38e2421944
(cherry picked from commit b9333125790682f9d60bc74fdbb12a098565e7c2)
(cherry picked from commit 831abc9f83a2d3f517030f881e7da724417fea93)

commit_message:
api: Log os-resetState as an instance action

It appears this was missed as this action never hits the compute API and
is fully handled within the API itself. This change simply records an
instance action directly in the API for this admin action providing a
breadcrumb to operators and users.

Closes-Bug: #1911924
Change-Id: Ifd9657f3357bc39cb904caa65168d38def8c9184
(cherry picked from commit 534b4f38958af2fbf4392e445ddb1b2bad4179ed)

Spent more time playing with this. And seems to work well with the test cases I used. I still think we may have to improve ranking object count weigting a bit (see the follow up patch I posted last week as an example). But that's not something that should stall this patch.

What we have here is pretty awesome, and does a good job! Improvments can come later when we have more real life expereience and as follow ups. Landing this will unlock a very useful tool that we can then also start to tie in to the auto-sharder! So great job Al."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-03-29 10:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

'}, {'created': '2020-12-10 14:24:02.000000000', 'message': "swift-manage-shard-ranges: add repair and analyze commands

Adds a repair command that reads shard ranges from the container DB,
identifies overlapping shard ranges and recommends how overlaps can be
repaired by shrinking into a single chosen path.  Prompted user input
or a '-y' option will then cause the appropriately modified shard
ranges to be merged into the container DB.

The repair command does not fix gaps in shard range paths and can
therefore only succeed if there is at least one unbroken path of
shards through the entire namespace.

Also adds an analyze command that loads shard data from a file and
reports overlapping shard ranges, but takes no action.  The analyze
command is similar to the repair command but reads shard data from
file rather than a container db and makes no changes to the db.

e.g.:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges db-file-name repair
  swift-manage-shard-ranges dummy-db-file-name analyze shard-data.json

for more detail:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges -v dummy-db-file-name analyze shard-data.json

The dummy-db-file-name is needed to keep argparse happy.

Change-Id: I9ec411462e4aaf9f21aba6c5fd7698ff75a07de3

or a '-y' option will then cause the appropriately modified shard
ranges to be merged into the container DB.

The repair command does not fix gaps in shard range paths and can
therefore only succeed if there is at least one unbroken path of
shards through the entire namespace.

Also adds an analyze command that loads shard data from a file and
reports overlapping shard ranges, but takes no action.  The analyze
command is similar to the repair command but reads shard data from
file rather than a container db and makes no changes to the db.

e.g.:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges <db-file-name> repair
  swift-manage-shard-ranges <shard-data.json> analyze

for more detail:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges -v <shard-data.json> analyze

commit_message:
swift-manage-shard-ranges: add repair and analyze commands

Adds a repair command that reads shard ranges from the container DB,
identifies overlapping shard ranges and recommends how overlaps can be
repaired by shrinking into a single chosen path.  Prompted user input
or a '-y' option will then cause the appropriately modified shard
ranges to be merged into the container DB.

The repair command does not fix gaps in shard range paths and can
therefore only succeed if there is at least one unbroken path of
shards through the entire namespace.

Also adds an analyze command that loads shard data from a file and
reports overlapping shard ranges, but takes no action.  The analyze
command is similar to the repair command but reads shard data from
file rather than a container db and makes no changes to the db.

e.g.:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges <db-file-name> repair
  swift-manage-shard-ranges <shard-data.json> analyze

to see more detail:
  swift-manage-shard-ranges -v <shard-data.json> analyze

For consistency with the new repair command, and to be more cautious,
this patch changes the user input required to apply the compact
command changes to the DB from 'y' to 'yes'.

Change-Id: I9ec411462e4aaf9f21aba6c5fd7698ff75a07de3

commit_message:
docs: Use proper headers in nova-manage man page

This is step one in improving the usability of these docs. The current
style makes it impossible to link to individual commands from the built
docs. There is a better way. Use headers along with code blocks to show
the actual command. This was mostly generated from a find-replace along
with some follow-up manual fixes.

Change-Id: Icd25006f31c8e34fe33d79779e0577dc78f96a24
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-12 18:37:12.000000000', 'message': "s3api: Transfer REMOTE_USER when using s3_acl

Some middlewares (notably staticweb) use the absence of a REMOTE_USER to
determine that a request was unauthenticated and as a sresult should be
handled differently. This could cause problems for S3 requests that
were authenticated via s3api's custom auth logic, including

* server errors when a container listing request gets handled by
  staticweb or
* losing storage policy information because staticweb copied the request
  environment.

Change-Id: Idf29c6866fec7b413c4369dce13c4788666c0934
Closes-Bug: #1833287
Related-Change: I5fe5ab31d6b2d9f7b6ecb3bfa246433a78e54808
"}, {'created': '2021-01-09 00:11:13.000000000', 'message': "s3api: Transfer REMOTE_USER when using s3_acl

Some middlewares (notably staticweb) use the absence of a REMOTE_USER to
determine that a request was unauthenticated and as a result should be
handled differently. This could cause problems for S3 requests that
were authenticated via s3api's custom auth logic, including

* server errors when a container listing request gets handled by
  staticweb or
* losing storage policy information because staticweb copied the request
  environment.

Change-Id: Idf29c6866fec7b413c4369dce13c4788666c0934
Closes-Bug: #1833287
Related-Change: I5fe5ab31d6b2d9f7b6ecb3bfa246433a78e54808
"}]
commit_message:
s3api: Transfer REMOTE_USER when using s3_acl

Some middlewares (notably staticweb) use the absence of a REMOTE_USER to
determine that a request was unauthenticated and as a result should be
handled differently. This could cause problems for S3 requests that
were authenticated via s3api's custom auth logic, including

* server errors when a container listing request gets handled by
  staticweb or
* losing storage policy information because staticweb copied the request
  environment.

Change-Id: Idf29c6866fec7b413c4369dce13c4788666c0934
Closes-Bug: #1833287
Related-Change: I5fe5ab31d6b2d9f7b6ecb3bfa246433a78e54808

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to

commit_message:
Avoid fact gathering for group_by

There are a few places where we have a play with one task that uses the
group_by module to generate groups that are used in a subsequent play.
These plays do not need to gather facts for their target hosts.

In particular, the kolla-openstack.yml playbook should really be able to
operate without access to remote hosts.

This change also adds changed_when: false to all group_by tasks, since
they show as changed but haven't really made any changes outside of
Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I18f67eda4e48058f3f402b9d0e692d6eeb02855f
(cherry picked from commit 388dfa369c9608f252dc946123c1801999931f6f)

commit_message:
Add networking-midonet to the list of deprecated projects

Due to lack of maintainers and as per discussion in the [1] we have to
deprecate networking-midonet project.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-March/021400.html

Change-Id: I15a42b1047dae5d3197c2cdf1a7dd9334c117514

commit_message:
Change all *Debug parameter types to boolean

This changes all these parameters as heat would correctly
parse all values. Also, drops all yaql shenanigans
used for their handling and heat conditions.

Also fixes wrong usage of non-existent NeutronWrapperDebug
parameter in ovn-metadata-container-puppet.yaml.

We had converted all ``Debug`` parameters to boolean with
Ib6c3969d4dd75d5fb2cc274266c060acff8d5571.

Change-Id: Ia2bffffde34aa248a4cc60c3895464f1f9d1ded2

commit_message:
Test proxy-server.conf-sample

AFAICT we don't test it anywhere in unittests; but I think we depend on
it for probe tests in the gate - it should definately be valid and
loadable.  We have lots of other tests that make proxy servers out of
configs - why not test this one if we can!

Change-Id: Iea9e01d5a66ccce6a73c7d23b358579194de89e2

subject: Use publish-to-pypi on barbican ansible roles
messages:
[{'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 06:52:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2021-03-31 08:05:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

To me it is a bit confusing to see the openstack/ansible-role-* namespace being shared by different projects, but I guess the precedent has been set by openstack/ansible-role-lunasa-hsm anyway, so single-approving this for consistency and in order to unblock the release process.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-03-31 08:46:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1
> 
> To me it is a bit confusing to see the openstack/ansible-role-* namespace being shared by different projects, but I guess the precedent has been set by openstack/ansible-role-lunasa-hsm anyway, so single-approving this for consistency and in order to unblock the release process.

Thank you Jens.

If I'm right the ownership these roles recently changed this is why those are under the barbican umbrella."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-31 06:52:38.000000000', 'message': 'Use publish-to-pypi on barbican ansible roles

These templates are missing and needed by:
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783908
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783905

Change-Id: I037d5add805b0e599caf6b24cfabcb6695ed568e
'}]
commit_message:
Use publish-to-pypi on barbican ansible roles

These templates are missing and needed by:
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783908
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/783905

Change-Id: I037d5add805b0e599caf6b24cfabcb6695ed568e

commit_message:
Drop the tripleo-puppet-undercloud job

... because Zaqar is no longer enabled in Undercloud by default.

Change-Id: I45e73ae0575165c305bac28284fb1aaa425509e0

subject: Retry update_user when sqlalchemy raises StaleDataErrors
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 8866, 'name': 'Raildo Mascena de Sousa Filho', 'email': 'rmascena@redhat.com', 'username': 'raildo'}, {'_account_id': 9954, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'username': 'lbragstad', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 11816, 'name': 'mike_mp@zzzcomputing.com', 'email': 'mike_mp@zzzcomputing.com', 'username': 'zzzeek'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 16465, 'name': 'Kristi Nikolla', 'email': 'knikolla@bu.edu', 'username': 'knikolla'}, {'_account_id': 21420, 'name': 'Gage Hugo', 'email': 'gagehugo@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghugo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

(1 comment)

since someone added me, here is my comment on this.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-08-27 21:20:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-08-27 21:21:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-08-28 13:50:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-09-09 22:07:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Michael,

I'm curious if you think this is a better approach than what we were using in previous patches. This isn't more selective in the update statement, like what Jay suggested, but it does attempt to retry if the update fails due to deadlock."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-09-10 13:39:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> Hi Michael,
 > 
 > I'm curious if you think this is a better approach than what we
 > were using in previous patches. This isn't more selective in the
 > update statement, like what Jay suggested, but it does attempt to
 > retry if the update fails due to deadlock.

it's OK but I'm wondering here what would produce the deadlock, unless you're referring to a galera write-set conflict which is not quite the same thing even though that's the error it raises.  IIUC this would emit an UPDATE statement on a row that did not already have an exclusive write lock on it, so InnoDB would just let the update proceed regardless of the previous state of the row.   InnoDB is actually not intuitive at all in how it does repeatable read and for writes it tends to act more like read-committed, https://blog.pythian.com/understanding-mysql-isolation-levels-repeatable-read/ is a good post on this.   full disclosure I never really know what a particular MySQL interaction is going to do unless I sit down and test it like he is doing in this blog post.

the compare-and-swap idea is actually using a specially crafted UPDATE statement that includes what we expect to be updating against, and then looking at the number of rows matched to confirm we hit those rows."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-10-21 20:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-10-21 20:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-10-21 21:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

I took a look at the error at https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1885753 and this doesn't look like a retry situation, it looks like a row is being deleted from "password".    These mappings aren't using the version_id_col feature, and have plain surrogate int primary keys, but it looks like the way the password gets changed is that a new instance of Password() is created, but then it's appending them to a collection, is that right?  it seems like the delete would be part of this step "truncate extra passwords" that's shortening the list:

        # truncate extra passwords
        if self.local_user.passwords:
            unique_cnt = CONF.security_compliance.unique_last_password_count
            unique_cnt = unique_cnt + 1 if unique_cnt == 0 else unique_cnt
            self.local_user.passwords = self.local_user.passwords[-unique_cnt:]

what's not clear is why it's trying to emit an UPDATE on the password table, since it looks like a row in password is only created, is that right?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-24 21:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> I took a look at the error at https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1885753 and this doesn't look like a retry situation, it looks like a row is being deleted from "password".    These mappings aren't using the version_id_col feature, and have plain surrogate int primary keys, but it looks like the way the password gets changed is that a new instance of Password() is created, but then it's appending them to a collection, is that right?

Yes - depending on keystone's configuration it keeps a list of passwords for PCI-DSS compliance.

  it seems like the delete would be part of this step "truncate extra passwords" that's shortening the list:
> 
>         # truncate extra passwords
>         if self.local_user.passwords:
>             unique_cnt = CONF.security_compliance.unique_last_password_count
>             unique_cnt = unique_cnt + 1 if unique_cnt == 0 else unique_cnt
>             self.local_user.passwords = self.local_user.passwords[-unique_cnt:]
> 
> what's not clear is why it's trying to emit an UPDATE on the password table, since it looks like a row in password is only created, is that right?

I think the updates is coming from the bit of code just below what you're referencing:

https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/src/branch/master/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py#L151-L154

I think the race happens when thread one pulls X passwords from the Password table, sets the new password, appends it to the list of current passwords for the user (handling the truncate), and before it can commit those changes thread two has truncated on of the passwords that thread one is trying to update the expiration for.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2021-03-24 21:25:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

OK, to prevent this kind of race if you have SELECTed the row already, two options are:

1. SELECT..FOR UPDATE.  This won't protect you on a galera multi-master configuration as the lock does not travel to other nodes.

2. use query.update() for a compare-and-swap approach.  check the number of rows affected and if you get 0, then figure out what it is you're supposed to do with the current data, if anything."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-24 22:59:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> OK, to prevent this kind of race if you have SELECTed the row already, two options are:
> 
> 1. SELECT..FOR UPDATE.  This won't protect you on a galera multi-master configuration as the lock does not travel to other nodes.
> 
> 2. use query.update() for a compare-and-swap approach.  check the number of rows affected and if you get 0, then figure out what it is you're supposed to do with the current data, if anything.

Ok, that helps.

If we were to use approach #2, would it make sense to keep the update at the user-level, or is there any advantage to using a separate transaction for passwords (this doesn't feel like a good idea, but I figured I'd ask anyway).

Also, if we get 0 rows affected from the database, is the most sensible thing to return a 4XX to the user (right now we're returning a 500)? Or should we just assume the password has already been removed and prune it from the list of passwords for the next update?"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2021-03-24 23:10:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > Patch Set 3:
> > 
> > OK, to prevent this kind of race if you have SELECTed the row already, two options are:
> > 
> > 1. SELECT..FOR UPDATE.  This won't protect you on a galera multi-master configuration as the lock does not travel to other nodes.
> > 
> > 2. use query.update() for a compare-and-swap approach.  check the number of rows affected and if you get 0, then figure out what it is you're supposed to do with the current data, if anything.
> 
> Ok, that helps.
> 
> If we were to use approach #2, would it make sense to keep the update at the user-level, or is there any advantage to using a separate transaction for passwords (this doesn't feel like a good idea, but I figured I'd ask anyway).

I don't totally understand the implications of "the user level" but overall I like to stick to a single transaction for an entire HTTP request in general unless you are trying to write out logging for the operation in progress separately.

> 
> Also, if we get 0 rows affected from the database, is the most sensible thing to return a 4XX to the user (right now we're returning a 500)? Or should we just assume the password has already been removed and prune it from the list of passwords for the next update?


Since I don't totally understand this datamodel / query as I havent looked at the whole thing, if the UPDATE is missing a row that the operation plans to DELETE, then that can be ignored, but if the UPDATE misses a row that the oepratino would assume still exists when the operation is complete then that's a 404.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-25 01:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:

> > Patch Set 3:
> >

> > > 
> > > 1. SELECT..FOR UPDATE.  This won't protect you on a galera multi-master configuration as the lock does not travel to other nodes.
> > > 
> > > 2. use query.update() for a compare-and-swap approach.  check the number of rows affected and if you get 0, then figure out what it is you're supposed to do with the current data, if anything.
> > 
> > Ok, that helps.
> > 
> > If we were to use approach #2, would it make sense to keep the update at the user-level, or is there any advantage to using a separate transaction for passwords (this doesn't feel like a good idea, but I figured I'd ask anyway).
> 
> I don't totally understand the implications of "the user level" but overall I like to stick to a single transaction for an entire HTTP request in general unless you are trying to write out logging for the operation in progress separately.
> 
> > 
> > Also, if we get 0 rows affected from the database, is the most sensible thing to return a 4XX to the user (right now we're returning a 500)? Or should we just assume the password has already been removed and prune it from the list of passwords for the next update?
> 
> 
> Since I don't totally understand this datamodel / query as I havent looked at the whole thing, if the UPDATE is missing a row that the operation plans to DELETE, then that can be ignored, but if the UPDATE misses a row that the oepratino would assume still exists when the operation is complete then that's a 404.

Perfect, I'll give that a shot and see if I can do that in the next patch set.

Thank you for the help, Mike.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-25 17:38:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > > If we were to use approach #2, would it make sense to keep the update at the user-level, or is there any advantage to using a separate transaction for passwords (this doesn't feel like a good idea, but I figured I'd ask anyway).
> > 
> > I don't totally understand the implications of "the user level" but overall I like to stick to a single transaction for an entire HTTP request in general unless you are trying to write out logging for the operation in progress separately.
> > 
> > > 
> > > Also, if we get 0 rows affected from the database, is the most sensible thing to return a 4XX to the user (right now we're returning a 500)? Or should we just assume the password has already been removed and prune it from the list of passwords for the next update?
> > 
> > 
> > Since I don't totally understand this datamodel / query as I havent looked at the whole thing, if the UPDATE is missing a row that the operation plans to DELETE, then that can be ignored, but if the UPDATE misses a row that the oepratino would assume still exists when the operation is complete then that's a 404.
> 
> Perfect, I'll give that a shot and see if I can do that in the next patch set.
> 
> Thank you for the help, Mike.

Following up on this again after more investigation:

I can recreate the LP issue consistently on older environments (~stable/queens). I'm unable to reproduce it using a devstack deployment with Wallaby. I tried to make the situation more likely to reproduce by 1.) increasing the number of clients making requests to update the same user and 2.) increase the number of processes serving keystone requests.

Still, even with those adjustments, I'm unable to recreate this issue. I diff'd the changes and found [0], which has minimal changes to that area of code.

However, if I revert that change on keystone's latest commit, I'm able to reproduce this issue. I'm still trying to figure out why that specific change may have fixed this issue, though.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/593476'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2021-03-25 17:43:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-30 16:57:27.000000000', 'message': "Leverage UPDATE FOR when updating users

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication times for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data. In other words,
two clients pull the user record when they enter update_user(), but the
slower of the two clients will fail because its reference to the user
is outdated when the first client updates the user as it exits the
method.

This commit mitigates this issue by using sqlalchemy's with_update_for()
method, which signals to SQL that the record we're selecting will be
updated. This helps the clients play nice together when they're updating
the same reference.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753
"}, {'created': '2020-07-08 17:02:12.000000000', 'message': "Leverage UPDATE FOR when updating users

This commit mitigates this issue by using sqlalchemy's with_update_for()
method, which signals to SQL that the record we're selecting will be
updated. This helps the clients play nice together when they're updating
the same reference.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753
"}, {'created': '2020-08-27 21:21:19.000000000', 'message': "Wrap update_user in wrap_db_retry

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication times for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data. In other words,
two clients pull the user record when they enter update_user(), but the
slower of the two clients will fail because its reference to the user
is outdated when the first client updates the user as it exits the
method.

This commit mitigates the issue by using @wrap_db_retry so that the
client recieving the deadlock tries its request again.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753
"}, {'created': '2021-03-25 22:17:35.000000000', 'message': "Wrap update_user in wrap_db_retry

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication attempts for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data when updating
password expiration for old passwords, which happens when setting a new
password for a user.

This commit attempts to handle that case more gracefully than throwing a
500 by detecting StaleData exceptions from sqlalchemy and issuring a
retry. The identity sql backend will retry the request for client that
have stale data change from underneath them.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753

commit_message:
Retry update_user when sqlalchemy raises StaleDataErrors

Keystone's update_user() method in the SQL driver processes a lot of
information about how to update users. This includes evaluating password
logic and authentication attempts for PSI-DSS. This logic is evaluated
after keystone pulls the user record from SQL and before it exits the
context manager, which performs the write.

When multiple clients are all updating the same user reference, it's
more likely they will see an HTTP 500 because of race conditions exiting
the context manager. The HTTP 500 is due to stale data when updating
password expiration for old passwords, which happens when setting a new
password for a user.

This commit attempts to handle that case more gracefully than throwing a
500 by detecting StaleDataErrors from sqlalchemy and retrying.  The
identity sql backend will retry the request for clients that have
stale data change from underneath them.

Change-Id: I75590c20e90170ed862f46f0de7d61c7810b5c90
Closes-Bug: 1885753

commit_message:
Get func tests passing with a minimal proxy pipeline

I've now got 54 pass, 676 skipped with

   pipeline = proxy-logging memcache tempauth proxy-logging proxy-server

Could probably even ditch logging, but that'd get a bit painful to
debug.

Change-Id: I86bcd7a2373cf1e7213cb716888307306b7bb50d

> > We have seen the upgrade job failure earlier and tracking bug is here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1921401 it is not frequent, it comes some times.
> 
> @Marios, Didn't we agree to make these upgrade jobs periodic?

Yes it's coming in due course. We have removed the master/non voting ones. It is TBD if we will be adding them for Xena.

Part of the wait is for the upgrades DFG to increase their downstream CI to fill in the gap.

We do and have had these jobs in the periodic/integration lines for a long time (and they are voting ie in the promotion criteria) already. We may add them into the upstream periodic lines too, once we remove from check/gate."}]

commit_message:
Don't allow rotation of HeatAuthEncryptionKey

Heat does not support rotation of auth_encryption_key
for existing deployments with heat stacks. Once this
key has been rotated exisiting stacks can't be updated
or even deleted. Let's not allow them to be changed.

Change-Id: I19c1d166ca72465fd4ae3dad46de77bb095f73d4
(cherry picked from commit 5db2ab20405a3406f208e56dfec0493e93aa0029)

[{'created': '2020-11-26 03:08:49.000000000', 'message': "NetApp SolidFire: Fix error on cluster workload rebalancing

When SolidFire is under heavy load or being upgraded, the
SolidFire cluster may automatically move connections from primary
to secondary nodes, in order to rebalance cluster workload.

Although this operation ocurrs very quickly, if an operation is made
to a volume at the same time it's being moved, there might be a
chance that API calls such as create snapshot could fail with
xNotPrimary error. Normally this will succeed on a retry of the
operation.

This patch fixes this issue by adding the xNotPrimary exception to
our list of retryable exceptions in the SolidFire driver.

Change-Id: I67dd2bfba37adcb7cda5f1cd08ff641410ec3f6b
Closes-Bug: #1891914
(cherry picked from commit 8d0c08b4bb9d32f2c02dcc60f1f482331197e546)

commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: Fix error on cluster workload rebalancing

When SolidFire is under heavy load or being upgraded, the
SolidFire cluster may automatically move connections from primary
to secondary nodes, in order to rebalance cluster workload.

Although this operation ocurrs very quickly, if an operation is made
to a volume at the same time it's being moved, there might be a
chance that API calls such as create snapshot could fail with
xNotPrimary error. Normally this will succeed on a retry of the
operation.

This patch fixes this issue by adding the xNotPrimary exception to
our list of retryable exceptions in the SolidFire driver.

Change-Id: I67dd2bfba37adcb7cda5f1cd08ff641410ec3f6b
Closes-Bug: #1891914
(cherry picked from commit 8d0c08b4bb9d32f2c02dcc60f1f482331197e546)
(cherry picked from commit 622244a755b75a52d079f92d8526f6eb5b517106)
(cherry picked from commit f087536e47a30349553f6e604ea804250d91022a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-26 04:15:40.000000000', 'message': "NetApp SolidFire: Fix duplicate volume when API response is lost

The SolidFire driver retries API requests in case a connection
error occurrs. When network is unstable, there may be the
possibility that the SolidFire backend successfully receive
and process a create volume operation, but fail to deliver the
response back to the driver.

When this scenario occurrs, the SolidFire driver automatically
resends the request, creating a second volume and leaving a
duplicate unused. Although this doesn't affect
driver functionality at first moment (the volume id from the
cluster is always correctly associated to cinder provider id),
further operations may hit the unused volume, leading to
unexpected hehavior.

This patch fixes this issue by:

1. Checking if the volume name already exists in the
backend before trying to create it. Volume creation will
raise a exception and abort in case of a volume is found.

2. Checking for volume creation right after a read timeout is
detected, preventing invalid API calls.

3. Adding option ´sf_volume_create_timeout´ to the SolidFire
driver, to allow users to set the appropriate timeout value for
their environment.

Closes-Bug: #1896112
Change-Id: I4383b691a8cc4aacb046332e418aafb88ba8ba56
(cherry picked from commit 42c92cc407d475751bc61c98445c9c0740a71496)

commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: Fix duplicate volume when API response is lost

The SolidFire driver retries API requests in case a connection
error occurrs. When network is unstable, there may be the
possibility that the SolidFire backend successfully receive
and process a create volume operation, but fail to deliver the
response back to the driver.

When this scenario occurrs, the SolidFire driver automatically
resends the request, creating a second volume and leaving a
duplicate unused. Although this doesn't affect
driver functionality at first moment (the volume id from the
cluster is always correctly associated to cinder provider id),
further operations may hit the unused volume, leading to
unexpected hehavior.

This patch fixes this issue by:

1. Checking if the volume name already exists in the
backend before trying to create it. Volume creation will
raise a exception and abort in case of a volume is found.

2. Checking for volume creation right after a read timeout is
detected, preventing invalid API calls.

3. Adding option ´sf_volume_create_timeout´ to the SolidFire
driver, to allow users to set the appropriate timeout value for
their environment.

Closes-Bug: #1896112
Change-Id: I4383b691a8cc4aacb046332e418aafb88ba8ba56
(cherry picked from commit 42c92cc407d475751bc61c98445c9c0740a71496)
(cherry picked from commit deb31a0c4d35ea6c479bfe466b780ed07a489276)
(cherry picked from commit d73da73283c783f90e878c5fbd53e114e1918f0a)

[{'created': '2021-03-09 21:28:01.000000000', 'message': '[Pure] Fix failing consistency group tempest tests

Currently CG tests have to be disabled due to this failing test. This
test will never succeed because the underlying array cannot create a
condition where this type of failure would occur.
This test has never passed due to the underlying fundamental
misunderstanding of the arrays internal logic mechanisms and should
never have been in the test suite in the first place.

Change-Id: I4923cda0e7b747c141203a024c325c4d2b8cea02
(cherry picked from commit 41101463a859a8dfb3ce06330ce50c380efe6209)
'}]
commit_message:
[Pure] Fix failing consistency group tempest tests

Currently CG tests have to be disabled due to this failing test. This
test will never succeed because the underlying array cannot create a
condition where this type of failure would occur.
This test has never passed due to the underlying fundamental
misunderstanding of the arrays internal logic mechanisms and should
never have been in the test suite in the first place.

Change-Id: I4923cda0e7b747c141203a024c325c4d2b8cea02
(cherry picked from commit 41101463a859a8dfb3ce06330ce50c380efe6209)

[{'created': '2021-03-26 08:52:42.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] Make delete_router_port() less error prone

This commit makes the delete_router_port() method from OVNClient more
resilient to NotFound errors. Apart from the L3 plugin, this method is
also invoked by the maintenance task to fix stale/not-up-to-date objects
in the OVN database, and since the maintenance task runs every 5 minutes
only it could happen that some objects fetched by delete_router_port()
are gone by the moment that method is invoked.

Change-Id: I0d78278797beb2af42ec38462e2b2edc8e2a4ae6
Closes-Bug: #1920968
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 36b8c684b1c42a0733d0820bcd2e1fe217f23797)
'}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Make delete_router_port() less error prone

This commit makes the delete_router_port() method from OVNClient more
resilient to NotFound errors. Apart from the L3 plugin, this method is
also invoked by the maintenance task to fix stale/not-up-to-date objects
in the OVN database, and since the maintenance task runs every 5 minutes
only it could happen that some objects fetched by delete_router_port()
are gone by the moment that method is invoked.

Change-Id: I0d78278797beb2af42ec38462e2b2edc8e2a4ae6
Closes-Bug: #1920968
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 36b8c684b1c42a0733d0820bcd2e1fe217f23797)

Don't sync networking-midonet requirements

As per discussion in [1], we need to deprecate networking-midonet as

commit_message:
Make functional tests set node_staging_uri

Currently it is not possible to configure the staging directory
URI of the functional workers. We need to be able to do that in order
to enable the stage cleaning behavior. Right now, they're all sharing
/tmp/staging, which will cause workers to conflict while running in
parallel. This causes them to use their private test directory,
which may also help some other spurious failures due to interaction.

Related-Bug: #1913625
Change-Id: Ic2ac2a528206c50c38e948a096daf9eb8e5eb715
(cherry picked from commit e9852fb6251c655f0e384c6b0b8677bd556f17a1)

commit_message:
Revert "Remove parameter nova::compute::pci_passthrough"

This should never have been merged.
It removed more than the deprecated param, breaking the pci config on
computes.
Also should have warned for at least 1 cycle before removal.
It also wasn't removed correctly as the pick remained in nova::compute::pci
so (IIUC) the deprecated param still works today if set in hieradata.

This reverts commit d845b6f0aefaaab0b65b32cd22ccda8c2c8ee6ae.

Change-Id: I5b3d9dbbd41d060134444609458b3e8bba606ae6
(cherry picked from commit e7f323a1f4fb37c5a8a70a123f08fc5e1e5a7843)
(cherry picked from commit 3f4d157b81e17582927c591303db399055fa44ea)

commit_message:
Don't configure dnsmasq entries for "network" ports

Ports with device_owner like:
* floating_ip,
* DHCP,
* some types of router ports, like: HA interface interface,
don't need to be configured in the dnsmasq file.
So there is no need to reload dnsmasq every time when such port is
added/updated to the network.

This patch adds skip in such case which should improve load on the
Neutron DHCP agent.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py

Closes-Bug: #1913269
Change-Id: I63221507713b941c261cdf88781133149da8ab8d
(cherry picked from commit e4bbeee2060058d079885339e99ef7e6e366de16)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-18 21:11:47.000000000', 'message': 'Option to enable bootloader config failure bypass

Some hardware is very well intentioned. However this intention
can result in the UEFI NVRAM table being full which prevents us
from adding new records to the table. We can't be sure what to
delete, so in this case some operators just need the ability to
tell ironic "it is okay if this fails, it will still work."

The added ``ignore_bootloader_failure`` option adds
this capability which can be set per-node either in the agent
configuation via the ramdisk image, or in the pxe_append_params
configuration parameter for the node itself with a
``ipa-ignore-bootloader-failure`` option in order to prevent
the failure from being raised.

Change-Id: If3c83fb2ea2025fce092d495a64f32077c70d2d6
Story: 2008386
Task: 41309
(cherry picked from commit 7a83773fbc9800217a0364c72b8ca9f823a60519)
(cherry picked from commit 07cf2c1b7921f37adf0dbf633fd0efed07ddbfd8)

commit_message:
Option to enable bootloader config failure bypass

Some hardware is very well intentioned. However this intention
can result in the UEFI NVRAM table being full which prevents us
from adding new records to the table. We can't be sure what to
delete, so in this case some operators just need the ability to
tell ironic "it is okay if this fails, it will still work."

The added ``ignore_bootloader_failure`` option adds
this capability which can be set per-node either in the agent
configuation via the ramdisk image, or in the pxe_append_params
configuration parameter for the node itself with a
``ipa-ignore-bootloader-failure`` option in order to prevent
the failure from being raised.

Change-Id: If3c83fb2ea2025fce092d495a64f32077c70d2d6
Story: 2008386
Task: 41309
(cherry picked from commit 7a83773fbc9800217a0364c72b8ca9f823a60519)
(cherry picked from commit 07cf2c1b7921f37adf0dbf633fd0efed07ddbfd8)

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Idd499e9029a2c975eeca61439d21e5b378394c8c

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-29 22:56:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix configuration generation for ironic doc pages

Ironic's sample configuration page previously did not render any
of the items in the default section, except for those items added
by other libraries. This was because we were trying to use an iterator
instead of a list.

Using an iterator, in theory should have worked, and did work for
normal invocations, but didn't work when it came to sphinx generated
output.

Instead of trying to use itertools to assemble everything, we just
now instead assemble the list and use a list_opts method like some
of the other more complex groups to add values.

Confirmed in local build output that the sphinx generated output
works as expected now.

Change-Id: I7f1cffb2a91728ab632ab0ccaa6acbb7e86fb533
"}]
commit_message:
Fix configuration generation for ironic doc pages

Ironic's sample configuration page previously did not render any
of the items in the default section, except for those items added
by other libraries. This was because we were trying to use an iterator
instead of a list.

Using an iterator, in theory should have worked, and did work for
normal invocations, but didn't work when it came to sphinx generated
output.

Instead of trying to use itertools to assemble everything, we just
now instead assemble the list and use a list_opts method like some
of the other more complex groups to add values.

Confirmed in local build output that the sphinx generated output
works as expected now.

Change-Id: I7f1cffb2a91728ab632ab0ccaa6acbb7e86fb533

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-25 12:36:29.000000000', 'message': "[DNM] Fix unit test case in TestListVnfLcmOp

It has been observe in review IDs [1] and [2] that the unit test
'tackerclient.tests.unit.osc.v1.test_vnflcm_op_occs.
TestListVnfLcmOp.test_take_action_with_filter'
is failing with  below error,
   DEBUG: TypeError: Object of type 'FormatComplexDataColumn'
   is not JSON serializable

A bug has been log for the same issue [3].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/636893
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/781314
[3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-tackerclient/+bug/1919350

Change-Id: I0d62f77cf5d1e9ec0b0a7c404abab83f97b708ba
"}, {'created': '2021-03-26 06:28:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix failing UT in TestListVnfLcmOp

The unit test 'tackerclient.tests.unit.osc.v1.test_vnflcm_op_occs.
TestListVnfLcmOp.test_take_action_with_filter' is failing with below
error message,
DEBUG: TypeError: Object of type 'FormatComplexDataColumn' is not
JSON serializable

Background:
In class TestListVnfLcmOp definition, "create_vnflcm_op_occs" function
is called and list of fake vnflcm op occs dictionary is store in
vnflcm_op_occs_obj.
Now this dictionary is used in two unit test cases "test_take_action"
and "test_take_action_with_filter".
In order to evaluate test results, in "test_take_action" test case,
"get_vnflcm_op_occ_data" function is called using "vnflcm_op_occs_obj"
which appends the data in dictionary.

Later this dictionary "vnflcm_op_occs_obj" is again used in
"test_take_action_with_filter".

Implementation:
This patch creates a separate list of fake vnflcm op occs dictionary for
both the test cases.

This issue has been impacting below reviews as well,
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/636893
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/781314

Closes-Bug: #1919350
Change-Id: I0d62f77cf5d1e9ec0b0a7c404abab83f97b708ba
'}]
commit_message:
Fix failing UT in TestListVnfLcmOp

The unit test 'tackerclient.tests.unit.osc.v1.test_vnflcm_op_occs.
TestListVnfLcmOp.test_take_action_with_filter' is failing with below
error message,
DEBUG: TypeError: Object of type 'FormatComplexDataColumn' is not
JSON serializable

Background:
In class TestListVnfLcmOp definition, "create_vnflcm_op_occs" function
is called and list of fake vnflcm op occs dictionary is store in
vnflcm_op_occs_obj.
Now this dictionary is used in two unit test cases "test_take_action"
and "test_take_action_with_filter".
In order to evaluate test results, in "test_take_action" test case,
"get_vnflcm_op_occ_data" function is called using "vnflcm_op_occs_obj"
which appends the data in dictionary.

Later this dictionary "vnflcm_op_occs_obj" is again used in
"test_take_action_with_filter".

Implementation:
This patch creates a separate list of fake vnflcm op occs dictionary for
both the test cases.

This issue has been impacting below reviews as well,
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/636893
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tackerclient/+/781314

Closes-Bug: #1919350
Change-Id: I0d62f77cf5d1e9ec0b0a7c404abab83f97b708ba

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-23 20:20:24.000000000', 'message': 'Don't configure dnsmasq entries for "network" ports

Ports with device_owner like:
* floating_ip,
* DHCP,
* some types of router ports, like: HA interface interface,
* distributed ports,
don't need to be configured in the dnsmasq file.
So there is no need to reload dnsmasq every time when such port is
added/updated to the network.

This patch adds skip in such case which should improve load on the
Neutron DHCP agent.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
    neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py

Closes-Bug: #1913269
Change-Id: I63221507713b941c261cdf88781133149da8ab8d
(cherry picked from commit e4bbeee2060058d079885339e99ef7e6e366de16)

commit_message:
Don't configure dnsmasq entries for "network" ports

Ports with device_owner like:
* floating_ip,
* DHCP,
* some types of router ports, like: HA interface interface,
don't need to be configured in the dnsmasq file.
So there is no need to reload dnsmasq every time when such port is
added/updated to the network.

This patch adds skip in such case which should improve load on the
Neutron DHCP agent.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
    neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py

Closes-Bug: #1913269
Change-Id: I63221507713b941c261cdf88781133149da8ab8d
(cherry picked from commit e4bbeee2060058d079885339e99ef7e6e366de16)

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature

I think Carlos raises a good question.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2021-03-29 19:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-03-30 00:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2021-03-30 00:23:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

I agree with Carlos in principle, but in practice I think this patch is the way to go.
While the purist in me would prefer to never silently ignore a config option (I believe I've gone on hour long mouth-frothing tirades about why I hate rsyslog and it's essentially because of this, so feeling a little hypocritical right now) I think that *breaking* loadbalancers is much worse, especially if this will just *happen* to all LBs by default, as Michael indicated. Also, assuming there's no newer image available (which is possible), this would break equally cryptically, requiring an operator (the user is helpless in this case as well) to track down why suddenly an entire fleet of loadbalancers just went to ERROR status and couldn't failover.

I am in favor of merging this change as-is."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-03-30 00:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

At least with this implementation users will report "ALPN h2 doesn't work" instead of the random failures they will get with the current implementation "Disabling a member caused my load balancer to fail and go offline".'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-03-30 00:30:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2021-03-30 00:31:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2021-03-30 13:42:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thanks all for the comments.

I ran the following manual upgrade test:

1. Deployed stable/ussuri with a Bionic amphora image, created a listener, TLS-enabled pool and a member. Confirmed all operating statuses were ONLINE and provisioning statuses ACTIVE. No ALPN settings applied, only available from Wallaby.
2. Upgraded Octavia to master. Left amphora image untouched.
3. Confirmed alpn_protocols is unset
    $ openstack loadbalancer pool show pool1 -f value -c alpn_protocols                                                                                                                                          
    None
4. Created second member in existing load balancer.
5. Confirmed no errors were raised in worker, health manager and amphora. Also confirmed no ALPN configuration was set in haproxy.cfg.
6. Deleted second member
7. Confirmed same as in point 5.

I believe this addresses the expressed concerns that existing load balancers (running old HAProxy versions) would be impacted upon adding/deleting members to existing pools.

Still, there is one more item to consider: what happens when an additional TLS-enabled pool and member are created on the same old load balancer? Here's my test and observations:

1. Created TLS-enabled pool, without passing in any ALPN protocols
2. Confirmed alpn_protocols is set to the default value (octavia.conf)
    $ openstack loadbalancer pool show pool2 -f value -c alpn_protocols
    ['h2', 'http/1.1', 'http/1.0']
3. Confirmed no errors were raised in worker, health manager and amphora.
4. Created member. The HAProxy backend server was set with ALPN properties and failed with same error message as attached to the story.
5. New member provisioning_status is in ERROR. All other load balancer objects are ONLINE/ACTIVE. HAProxy reverted to a good haproxy.cfg (i.e. new member excluded).

I would think the question now is: what should we do in this case, if any at all? Load balancer owners cannot create members on pools created *after* the upgrade. An update amphora image would solve this problem with either a manual failover or making an additional create/update/delete operation to the load balancer or its children which would trigger a failover via the health manager. *BUT* if the cloud operator does not upload an updated amphora image / stick with the old one, load balancers will go on an endless failover loop.

So, I would like to ask for feedback about this edge scenario: octavia upgraded except that amphora image was not which I'd think is unlikely to happen and strongly recommended to update (the upgrade guide is clear about this step --https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/admin/guides/upgrade.html): should we a )move forward with this patch potentially not honoring and hiding the desired ALPN configuration or b) assume cloud operators upload a new amphora image at upgrade phase?

Marking CR-1 to signal community feedback's been solicited."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2021-03-30 13:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

In my previous comment, where it reads:
"Load balancer owners cannot create members on pools created *after* the upgrade."

It should be:
"Load balancer owners cannot create members on *NEW* pools created *after* the upgrade."'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-03-30 14:29:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> In my previous comment, where it reads:
> "Load balancer owners cannot create members on pools created *after* the upgrade."
> 
> It should be:
> "Load balancer owners cannot create members on *NEW* pools created *after* the upgrade."

Well, I think it is they can't do anything with the load balancer after creating a new pool because any update will push the broken config.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2021-03-30 16:49:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Backport-Candidate+2 Code-Review+2

Michael and I further discussed this offline, including alternative solution paths. I am convinced now this patch provides the best balanced solution. I will let Greg, who also reviewed this patch earlier, have another look and approve it.
Michael, thank you for reporting the bug, proposing a fix and taking the time to chat a bit more.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2021-03-30 17:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2021-03-30 17:45:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)'}]

commit_message:
Fix pool ALPN compatibility with older amphora

The ALPN for pools patch introduced a bug that causes amphora to
fail if the HAProxy version running inside the amphroa does not
support ALPN on backend members (bionic images for example).
This patch adds compatibility support for those older HAProxy versions
by removing the ALPN configuration settings if the HAProxy version
is too old to support the functionality.

Story: 2008780
Task: 42171
Change-Id: Iac949431f0901aaa0a60e5c39c2aab44cb9c1970

commit_message:
Fix incorrect ERROR status with IPv6 UDP members

Some IPv6 UDP members were incorrectly marked in ERROR status because of
a formatting issue between the keepalived configuration file and the
ipvsadm output. Both are used to compute the state of the members and
when a member's address contained '*:0:*', parsing was incorrect. Now
the health message generation function uses only the compressed IPv6
notation instead of mixing notations.

Story: 2008604
Task: 41783

Conflicts:
    octavia/amphorae/backends/utils/keepalivedlvs_query.py

Change-Id: I2fe94cd4c000f143c59c69e82d03c690acf5e0c3
(cherry picked from commit e5f9f6708c70313bd7e0c570f3541c0afb7fc09c)
(cherry picked from commit 8b210bb52a6c44b3bd69acdf2202d1625e763fb6)
(cherry picked from commit 4b8de86cf3b2347e38d3a39435c8b609fb055404)

Fix pool ALPN compatibility with older amphora

The ALPN for pools patch introduced a bug that causes amphora to
fail if the HAProxy version running inside the amphroa does not
support ALPN on backend members (bionic images for example).
This patch adds compatibility support for those older HAProxy versions
by removing the ALPN configuration settings if the HAProxy version
is too old to support the functionality.

subject: Expose a few more headers in CORS responses
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-12 01:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-12 22:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can you point to or elaborate on the justification for this?  Is there a use-case?  Does some client expect this?  Does the spec call for it?  Should we be using a black-list instead?'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Does "I've got a gut feeling that these should matter" count as a justification? These were just curious things that I noticed were already getting returned but *weren't* exposed.

The spec's pretty clear on what it considers "safe": https://www.w3.org/TR/cors/#simple-response-header

Anything beyond that is at the discretion of the server. But Content-Length, for example, is effectively already exposed to you on GETs, and would be rather handy to have on HEADs. Content-Range would be good to confirm that it matches what you've already requested with your Range header.

A blacklist seems... more risky. Maybe it'd ultimately be a good idea? But certainly the spec is all about whitelisting things.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-01 21:11:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-01 21:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-03-31 00:34:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}]

commit_message:
Expose a few more headers in CORS responses

Allow, Date, Content-Length, and Content-Range should all be safe,
CORS-spec be damned.

Change-Id: I8e973bfc97647ecdeb78a57ab42589830b4fb544

example).

commit_message:
Use quay.ceph.io to pull the Ceph Dashboard related images

The purpose of this change is just to switch to quay.ceph.io
and pull from that location the Ceph Dashboard related images.
quay.ceph.io is maintained by the Ceph organization and can
be trusted to find the tags that we need.

Closes-Bug: #1920873
Change-Id: If5ec5d4fa0d4d835561b5963d244e5172fe82cc8
(cherry picked from commit 72c7d4ac71d33c8803120767108c6bf2ffeb2edc)

commit_message:
Fix symmetric algorithms and key lengths matching

This patch fixes an error key length check. For example,
AES only supports 128/192/256 lengths.

Without this patch Barbican can generate the wrong length keys.

Change-Id: Ia95d1326475ad821353a193edfa25fd51d26a678

commit_message:
relinker: Clean up probe tests a bit

* Include an object that *does not* get overwritten while relinking
* Ensure that org_locations only tracks the locations for the old diskfiles
* Be cautious of partition-0 diskfiles that do not move
* Ensure hashes.pkl is up-to-date before relinking

Change-Id: I8b7dfecd040a8c4532f35afd6e6aa995b6d4fe1e
